Barcelona recently made a supplementary tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential tax discrepancies, but the case remains under investigation. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway in a Mazda Premacy. Both men died in the accident. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for retired individuals, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of allowing older people to drive for as long as possible. Luciw's family and colleague, Andy Harrington, who was driving the van, suggest that medical examinations should be mandatory for retired drivers. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-assess every three years to renew their licenses, but no medical or driving tests are required. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents and has no plans to restrict licensing based on age.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse, leading to debilitating side effects for many women. Two patients resigned from the original review group in protest over a perceived watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, was tasked with examining the final report's process and conclusions. The report recommended against routine use of the implants for pelvic organ prolapse and suggested offering patients a range of treatments with informed choices, while also calling for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the recommendations are being implemented, as the government lacks the power to ban the procedures, which is regulated by the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members, and several members resigned over concerns about the report's integrity. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received these implants, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old record in the 5K race at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, achieving a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds, which is 14 seconds faster than McColgan's previous record. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken but initially questioned whether Muir's race met UK Athletics' criteria for a "genuine race" due to Muir being the only competitor in the 5K. British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be ratified as official, with no requirement for drug tests if there was no doping control at the event. McColgan praised Muir's potential to win world medals and suggested that Muir could improve her 5K time to around 14.30 minutes, which would place her among the world's top runners.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze, while GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, had a faultless show-jumping performance but was hindered by time penalties in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions an opportunity to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics and encourages readers to explore equestrian sports and subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter.

In a closely contested match, British tennis player Andy Murray defeated Italian Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Fognini had multiple opportunities to force a fifth set but Murray rallied to win five consecutive games. Murray will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week of the tournament. Murray described the match as tense and up and down, acknowledging that he didn't play his best tennis but managed to win.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death. Police found alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, leading to the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge criticized the lax adherence to licensing laws and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

In his speech launching the party's manifesto, Mike Nesbitt emphasized the need for partnership over domination, stating "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." He focused on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle as a key issue for the election. Nesbitt defended his comments about potentially partnering with the SDLP after the election, despite criticism from his party colleague Danny Kennedy. He expressed confidence in his position and highlighted the manifesto's focus on issues like tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and addressing Brexit impacts. Nesbitt also criticized the current administration for incompetence and corruption, hoping this message would resonate more than the controversy over his remarks.

The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aiming to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales in granting automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Known as 'Turing's Law', after Alan Turing, the law will provide posthumous pardons and allow living men to apply for pardons. The motion is expected to include these provisions, ensuring equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland. The minister secured executive agreement to request the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion for pardoning convictions related to abolished sexual offences, with the goal of implementing these arrangements as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This record surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 time of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish records for the 1500m and mile, expressed her satisfaction with the achievement. She hopes to secure a spot for the Olympics in Rio through the British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. Muir's training is balanced with her veterinary studies, which she is currently pursuing.
The passage highlights pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as "most excellent" for their water quality.

The passage discusses the 2006 poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London, which UK officials believe was carried out by Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. Richard Horwell QC, representing the Metropolitan Police, argued that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, citing the use of polonium-210, a radioactive substance, as evidence of state involvement. Horwell emphasized that while the Russian state was implicated, it did not necessarily mean President Vladimir Putin was directly involved. Litvinenko, a former Russian intelligence officer who defected to the UK, had made numerous criticisms of Putin, which could have contributed to his assassination. The suspects left a trail of polonium, but have not provided credible explanations for the evidence against them. Extradition attempts have failed, and the suspects remain in Russia. The inquiry was adjourned until a later date.

The passage highlights that Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the captain of Australia's Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch, and will also lead the one-day side. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and congratulated him on his ongoing appointment. Michael Clarke, 34, announced his retirement after the Ashes defeat, making Smith's role as successor straightforward. Smith had previously captained the team in three Tests against India while Clarke was recovering from injuries. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, has matured and is seen as a suitable vice-captain. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval on August 20.

The passage discusses Mr. Farron's stance on LGBT-plus rights, emphasizing his commitment to equality and his desire to extend marital rights to transgender people. He refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners." Mr. Farron clarified that he supports equality and is passionate about LGBT-plus rights, which he intends to prioritize as the leader of the liberal party. He mentioned the spousal veto as a barrier to transgender people's equal access to marriage and expressed his support for equal access under the law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

The passage discusses the closure of Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, which resulted in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare has now taken over the plant for pharmaceutical production, with the expectation that many of the jobs will be filled by former Sanofi employees. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area, according to a spokesman. Councillor Nick Forbes of Newcastle City Council views the development as fantastic news for the region, enhancing its reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, commented that these departures reflect the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff and anticipates further departures in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for the trio's dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, experienced a crash at this year's TT, and his Fireblade bike has faced mechanical issues. Initially, Martin announced his departure from road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he has no plans to race on Hondas this year. He did not participate in the North West 200 after his team-mate's crash and will also skip the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster and expressed his role as a test rider. After testing at Cadwell, he informed the team that the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. Martin now intends to focus on racing classics and other unique events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the recent elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll, will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's decline was further reinforced by the gubernatorial and state assembly elections, losing key northern states and control of Adamawa, which has been affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's historic gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to achieve a national spread of votes. The APC also retained power in Lagos state, the commercial capital, for the first time since multi-party democracy began in 1999. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP will need to introspect

The passage discusses allegations made by US-based environmental lobby group Mighty against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses both companies of potentially encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Southeast Asia, particularly through slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, denies the allegations and claims to have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Temasek also rejects the claims, stating it supports no-burn policies and does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies. The report highlights the global palm oil industry's troubled track record, including accusations of deforestation and illegal labor practices. Mighty also raises concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of bulldozing rainforests for palm oil plantations. Olam defends its practices in Gabon, asserting that its operations are transparent and sustainable.

The passage reports that a restaurant started serving "puppy platters" on 27 August 2016, following the introduction of a new law that allowed dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they were outdoors. The clip mentioned in the passage showcases the unique dining experience for dogs at the restaurant.

The passage highlights the fitness status of key players for an upcoming game. Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only played as a substitute in the last two matches. Derby County striker David Nugent, recovering from a groin injury, may return after missing the previous game. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who scored a late equalizer off the bench, is hoping for a starting position.

The passage discusses the lifting of Pakistan's ban on YouTube, imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) stated that the ban was no longer necessary as Google had launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the lifting of the ban, some activists called for greater transparency in the deal between Google and the government. The PTA can now request Google to block access to offending material directly through an online web process, though Google maintains that government requests for content removal will not be automatically granted. YouTube's community guidelines and country-specific laws will guide content restrictions after thorough review. Google recently launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, the head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and his potential conflict of interest due to sharing nationality with one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections for the same reason but has not done so for the upcoming election on February 26. LFA boss Musa Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Scala's spokesman argues that there is no conflict of interest as there is no incumbent president in this election. The election to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter involves five candidates and will be held in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday. A forensic search was conducted, and evidence suggests a flashover explosion occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, causing a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf, which were resolved after an apology. Morocco's participation was initially banned but allowed after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the decision. Tunisia and Morocco are now preparing for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia set to face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, and Morocco facing Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Tunisia's dispute with Caf centered around a contentious penalty awarded during their 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, which they lost. The issue was resolved through discussions with Caf president Issa Hayatou, ensuring Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament.

In a match at Etihad Stadium where Chelsea won 3-1, a mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute, resulting in Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, stemming from a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho, who clashed with Cesc Fabregas during the scuffle, was given a three-match ban. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot focusing on patients whose family doctors are concerned about cancer but show no urgent signs or symptoms. This follows a visit by Welsh doctors to Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, where they found improved cancer detection rates. The concern is that undiagnosed cancer in Wales often leads to delayed treatment due to unclear symptoms, resulting in multiple tests over several weeks. The pilot aims to refer 40 doctors' patients to the Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days for various tests, hoping for same-day results. Currently, only 35% of "worrisome" symptomatic patients in Cwm Taf receive a diagnosis. The goal is to reach the majority of asymptomatic patients faster. Another trial will be established in Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of the Swansea Bay University Health Board's pilot. The trials were developed after Welsh experts returned from Aarhus. Denmark established diagnostic centers due to concerns about lagging cancer detection rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, believes the plan will ease patient anxiety and speed up the process. Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdare, suggests the pilot could significantly impact

England secured a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. The hosts achieved their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs, with England making 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it one of the best innings he has seen. Pakistan struggled on a pitch that offered little assistance to bowlers, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. The series is expected to remain tight, with Pakistan looking to regain confidence before the third Test at Edgbaston on August 3.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has appointed interim coach Rob Howley and forwards coach Robin McBryde as part of his backroom team. McBryde will take on head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips expects to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide valuable development opportunities.

In a match where Hull City faced Southampton, Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control. Hull struggled with injuries to key strikers and appeared to lack attacking threat. However, the game turned in Hull's favor with two quick second-half goals from Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull held on for their first league win since August, ending a six-game losing streak. Hull's victory was aided by David Marshall's impressive saves and a crucial goal-line clearance by Sam Clucas. The win was significant for Hull, who had been struggling both on the field and with fan dissatisfaction.

A crash occurred at 14:15 BST on the B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa. A local motorcyclist was killed, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses and closed the B1191 between the B1192 Tattershall Road and A158 Jubilee Way junctions.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This decision was condemned by both the opposition and EU officials. Macedonia has been in turmoil since the recordings were released in 2015, which allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who has been releasing these recordings since February 2015, accuses the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and engaging in corruption. The government denies these accusations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilize the country. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn stated that Ivanov's actions are not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement being the top choice. The club is concerned about the possibility of relegation, as the Championship has become more competitive. Swansea rose from near bankruptcy and almost relegation out of the Football League in 2003 to promotion to the Premier League in 2011, establishing a reputation for well-run operations and exciting, possession-based football. Curtis, a former player, believes Swansea has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing it to frequent management changes. Despite this, Curtis thinks the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation, emphasizing the importance of the club's history and its impact on the local area.

The passage details a match where Dagenham & Redbridge (The Daggers) faced off against Leyton Orient. The Daggers, who had reached League One in 2010, needed a victory to maintain their slim chances of survival in the league. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, which followed an initial 2-0 lead by Leyton Orient through Jay Simpson, Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal led to Dagenham's relegation and kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who first entered the Football League in 2007, now return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led them from the Conference to League One. The Daggers have the worst goal difference in League Two and have struggled both defensively and offensively this season. Meanwhile, Orient's victory leaves them two points behind the play-off spots, following the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan. Both managers, John Still and interim manager Andy Hessenthaler, expressed their commitment to their respective clubs' futures in post-match interviews.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and retired in November after a 19-year career, has expressed his ambition to become a manager in the future. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp described Gerrard's appointment as "wonderful news" and believes Gerrard's playing experience combined with his willingness to learn positions him for a bright future in management.

In the match, McManus scored first with a close-range goal in the 15th minute, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected strike, giving Morton a 2-0 lead. Alloa managed to pull back with a goal by Kyle McAusland before halftime. However, Morton secured their win with additional goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone, resulting in a comfortable victory for the hosts.

Ofsted has discovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three locations in Birmingham, which have since been closed. The owners of these locations are under investigation for running illegal schools, which could result in a jail term of up to 51 weeks. The government is consulting on plans to increase regulation for places offering more than 6 to 8 hours of teaching per week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, expressed concern that the cases uncovered may be just the "tip of the iceberg" and that children could be at risk of abuse or radicalization. Any place teaching children for more than 20 hours a week must register as a school. Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some unregistered schools are exploiting the legal right to home education to operate illegally. The government has allocated funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against identified unregistered schools. The consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh and is set to be the first distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the potential to establish the region as a "region of distilling excellence" and emphasizes the unique scale of their production, operating from a small still in a cowshed. The gin aims to capture the local flavor palette using indigenous botanicals from the Teviot valley. John Henderson of Born in the Borders views the distillery as a complementary addition to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site, emphasizing their shared ethos of local sourcing. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, reflecting the distillery's connection to the local landscape and its female production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal driving limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law due to the incident occurring on private land. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) found Green's behavior to be reckless, and the family of Harry Whitlam expressed their grief and hope for remembering the positive aspects of his life.

The passage discusses the ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) on Luis Suarez's ban from football-related activities, which was imposed by FIFA after he bit Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. CAS upheld most of the sanctions but deemed the ban on all football activities as "excessive." As a result, Suarez is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches, attend games, and participate in promotional activities. He will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games and is likely to make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on October 26. World players' union FIFPro expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not significantly reduced and remain disproportionate. Suarez's legal team argued that FIFA misapplied its rules and that the sanction was disproportionate. The ruling allows Suarez to join Barcelona's first team training and be publicly presented as a new player on Monday, though it is uncertain if he will play in the game against Mexico's Club Leon.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who was carrying his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The competitors trained for a week and faced a challenging 380-metre course involving hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. The race allowed various combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Rich and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, addressing concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA, assured that the transition from paper tax discs to an electronic system in October would lead to changes in job roles rather than redundancies. The new system, announced by Chancellor George Osborne, allows for monthly direct debit payments and is expected to reduce the need for refunds, potentially altering job requirements. Hammond committed to redeploying affected employees to other areas within the agency, a move welcomed by Mike Hedges, who expressed relief that the focus would be on redeployment rather than job cuts.

The passage discusses Hungary's stance on three contentious laws: tight controls on asylum seekers, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law affecting the Central European University (CEU). Hungary's Foreign Minister, Peter Szijjarto, asserts that these laws are within national competence and opposes EU interference. He claims Poland will veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of its voting rights. Critics argue these laws could lead to the closure of CEU and stigmatize NGOs. The EU has warned of potential action if Hungary does not make positive changes.

The passage announces the casting and production details for the live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Belle's father, Maurice, and Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts. Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in "Frozen," will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Bill Condon, director of "Dreamgirls" and the last two "Twilight" films, will direct the movie, which begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios and is set for release on March 17, 2017, in the US.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist known for his controversial yet brilliant writing, passed away after a battle with multiple cancers. He was described as the "heart and soul" of The Sunday Times, where he worked since 1993. Gill was celebrated for his wit, fearless writing, and compassion. Despite his illness, he remained stoical and continued to write until his final column, which will be featured in the upcoming Sunday Times. Gill's career was marked by both praise and controversy, with many fellow journalists and writers paying tribute to his impact and legacy.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and the lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. Russian news reports indicate he was hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating but has called local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar wore a red deel embroidered with a swastika, which, though associated with the Nazis, is a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Hitler. His father reported that Sukhbaatar spent about 10 days in a coma after the assault, which involved being hit in the face with a metal object. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified. The Russian embassy is examining press and social media reports, noting that they are "distorted." The swastika, believed to have originated in India, is used in Mongolia as a symbol of eternity and is frequently worn by Sukhbaatar on stage. His lawyer, father, and a band member denied social media reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. The suspect in the beating has not been arrested, and the case is under

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest on Monday against the airport's expansion plans, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. The protest occurred at 03:30 BST on the northern runway. The Metropolitan Police announced a review of airport security, and the individuals involved will appear in court on 19 August.

Glamorgan's innings was highlighted by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, marking his second first-class century. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets in cloudy conditions, keeping the bowlers dominant throughout the day. Gloucestershire struggled against the bowling attack, with Selman's century being a significant return to form after a series of low scores. Aneurin Donald contributed with a quick-fire 36 off 30 balls, while Taylor and Miles excelled in the afternoon. Glamorgan managed a consolation bonus point, and the day ended with the match evenly balanced. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Selman expressed satisfaction with his performance, acknowledging the challenges of opening in county cricket, while Taylor noted the opportunities for bowlers and the challenges ahead for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after discussing plans to ambush and murder police officers on the Dee Estuary with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He planned to make a false police report to lure officers to the scene, where he intended to shoot them. The threats were made while Hughes was drunk and on two separate occasions. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, noting Hughes' previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Hughes' legal team argued he had no intention of carrying out the threats or harming himself. North Wales Police was particularly concerned as Hughes was on bail for firearms offences at the time, which he was later cleared of. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to those in need.

The passage describes a cricket match where Surrey, after being reduced to 8-2, scored 255-7, largely due to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, including key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire was all out for 236. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised the team's performance, particularly Davies and Foakes' partnership, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment, highlighting the need for better performance in crucial moments.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, experienced flooding issues due to a malfunctioning pump. The crew radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST for assistance. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a working pump on board and towed the vessel to Holyhead for safety.

The passage discusses the decision of Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over participating in the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, stated that her exams in May conflicted with the April event, making it impossible for her to attend. She expressed disappointment but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. Muir also mentioned her potential participation in the World Indoor Championships in March and her aspirations for future Olympics. Additionally, the passage highlights Muir's new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m event at the World Athletics Championships.

In his BBC Sport column, football pundit Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's current struggles compared to their previous season's title challenge. He attributes their decline to the loss of key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, who contributed significantly to their goal-scoring prowess. Savage also criticizes Liverpool's transfer market decisions, particularly in acquiring strikers who do not fit their system. He highlights the team's lack of intensity and leadership, especially in defense, and suggests that their current squad is not capable of challenging for the title. Savage predicts a difficult match against Chelsea, who he believes are far superior at the moment. Despite these challenges, he sees Steven Gerrard as a crucial player for Liverpool's future, praising his resilience and potential to continue contributing at a high level.

The Â£45m facility planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He authored the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, and was also a significant poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

A sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was discovered near the town, leading to the evacuation of an area near the swimming pool and safety advice for residents within 500m. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea, affecting ferry services and small boat owners. The Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit is handling the mine, which is deteriorated and cannot be accurately assessed for explosive content. The evacuation was precautionary, and there was no immediate danger to the community.

The passage discusses the funding cuts and allocations for various Olympic and Paralympic sports in preparation for the Tokyo 2020 Games. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 sports, £2m less than the record amount allocated for the Rio Games. Cycling, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have had their funding reduced or removed. Badminton, despite achieving a medal in Rio, has lost its funding, leading to concerns from Badminton England. UK Sport has set Team GB targets of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. The decision to cut funding was not taken lightly, with UK Sport prioritizing to protect medal potential. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have also faced funding issues, questioning UK Sport's commitment to these sports. New sports added to the Tokyo 2020 program, such as baseball/softball and karate, await confirmation of their funding.

The passage discusses a proposed development in East Cliff, Bournemouth, where three Victorian hotels will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development due to its impact on the designated conservation area. However, councillors voted 7-3 in favor, citing benefits to tourism and improved living conditions for older residents. The new site will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. Despite objections from 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argue the demolished buildings retain historic character, the project is moving forward.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely in Brecon while off-duty. Vallely, 24, will be sentenced on December 8th. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Pte Boyd's body was found unconscious by police on May 8th. The attack occurred outside The Cellar bar, with CCTV capturing the assault. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. The community was shocked by the incident, and a family tribute described Pte Boyd as a loving and caring individual with a promising career cut short.

Andrew Travers, former chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following an error that led to voters being turned away from 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, with Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton temporarily taking over. Travers expressed pride in the changes and growth initiatives during his tenure, while the council acknowledged his valuable contributions. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, but concerns about the fairness of the election result persisted. Travers attributed the issue to electoral registration lists, and the council's review, set to conclude by the end of May, will assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum.

In a match between Gateshead and Wrexham, Josh Gillies scored a free-kick to give Gateshead an early lead, but Wrexham equalized before halftime with a set-piece by Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance. The final score was Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are at the bottom.

The passage discusses the ambitious OneWeb project, which aims to create a global broadband network using a constellation of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000. The project, a collaboration between OneWeb and Airbus, seeks to provide internet access to every school worldwide. To achieve this, Airbus has adopted high-volume, low-cost manufacturing methods, similar to those used in car and plane factories, aiming to produce three satellites per shift for less than a million dollars each. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The project requires the largest rocket campaign in spaceflight history, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles scheduled to launch clusters of satellites. OneWeb and Airbus face competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing, but OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional loans. OneWeb, registered in the UK's Channel Islands, works closely with the UK Space Agency, which is particularly interested in debris mitigation to prevent space pollution. OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting redundant satellites within two years to mitigate debris risks. The project's manufacturing

The passage discusses the financial challenges faced by the Scottish government due to the UK government's recent spending review, which imposes significant cuts on public expenditure in Scotland. Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney argues that these cuts, combined with previous reductions since 2010, will result in a 12.5% decrease in the Scottish government's discretionary budget by 2019-20. Swinney emphasizes that the Scottish government is committed to protecting key services like schools, hospitals, and the police, despite the cuts. The UK government responds by stating that the Scottish government will have an additional £390m in spending next year, and suggests that Scotland should focus on utilizing its new powers effectively. Labour criticizes the Scottish government's approach, calling for a long-term budget that offers a real alternative to austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities, their families, and carers when accessing suitable toilet facilities, particularly when they require more than standard accessible toilets. These individuals often need enhanced facilities, such as those provided by Changing Places toilets, which include extra space and features like hoists and changing benches. Despite recommendations for installing these facilities in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and sports stadiums, they are not yet compulsory, leading to feelings of isolation and stress for users and their families. Campaigners, including parents like Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers, are advocating for mandatory inclusion of Changing Places toilets in building regulations to ensure accessibility for all. The passage also highlights positive examples, such as Arsenal Football Club, which installed a Changing Places toilet and received positive feedback from the community.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's has defended its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and that this approach has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the antitrust complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate the charges. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are locked into long contracts and lease premises at above-market rates, leading to higher prices and reduced consumer choice. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014. The European Commission will now study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed founded.

The passage describes a social media campaign initiated by Bangor Elim Church to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began with a hashtag, #prayforjosh, on Facebook and Instagram, which quickly went viral, garnering over 79,000 views and support from people worldwide. A mystery donor funded a billboard with the hashtag in Holywood, further amplifying the support. The campaign has led to a global outpouring of support for Josh, with people from all over the world praying for his recovery.

The passage discusses the proposed closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales, a historic military site that has been in operation since 1805. The decision has been met with strong opposition from local MP Chris Davies, who argues that the closure shows a lack of respect for the barracks' long history and its role in numerous conflicts. Davies plans to fight the decision and has launched a petition, citing concerns about the impact on local employment and the military tourism industry. The closure is part of a broader UK military reorganisation, which includes the creation of a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and the eventual closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. While the Defence Secretary supports the restructuring, the Shadow Defence Secretary warns of the potential negative impact on the livelihoods of those employed at the bases.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting both risks and opportunities. It notes that fishing regions in the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU, hoping to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the industry, which contributes only a small fraction to the UK's GDP, might be a low priority for the government but must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report emphasizes the need for continued market access, which may come at the cost of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. It also suggests that many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK must continue to cooperate with neighboring states. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit presents, particularly in terms of sustainable fisheries management and fair access to quota.

The passage discusses the revelations made by Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, about the extensive surveillance activities of the US National Security Agency (NSA). Snowden disclosed that the NSA has access to a vast amount of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking information. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call details. The NSA also allegedly had "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, and Facebook, though these companies denied involvement. The surveillance is defended as necessary for national security, but critics argue it infringes on privacy. Different countries have varying data protection laws, and the passage also touches on the implications of cloud computing and data storage in the context of surveillance.

The passage discusses the formation of OpenAI, a venture backed by notable figures and companies including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. OpenAI aims to conduct AI research without financial constraints, focusing on a "positive human impact." Concerns have been raised by scientists, including Musk and Stephen Hawking, about the potential existential threat AI poses to humanity. However, other experts believe the risk remains remote. OpenAI's mission is to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity, emphasizing the importance of AI as an extension of human wills and ensuring its safe and equitable distribution. The venture plans to spend only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a Doncaster-based soldier seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite his brain injury affecting his speech, he remains determined, humorous, and caring. He spends 12 hours daily in gym and rehab, uses crutches, and actively supports military charities, including being a patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His Facebook page received thousands of friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit, and his mother, Diane, noted the phenomenal public support. Facebook suggested he consider a public page or subscription option to manage the high volume of requests. Parkinson's torch-carrying role was part of the 8,000-mile, 70-day journey to the London Olympic Games opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the U.S. remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, after three years of increases. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty in the U.S. had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and has extended his contract with the club until 2019. He holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and his contribution to the team's T20 Blast final win at Edgbaston. Buttler, currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted, and bidders are finalizing their bids with viewings scheduled for late February and March. A final decision is expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the UK's industry capacity in this field. Penny Mordaunt, a Conservative MP, supports giving UK recyclers a chance to prove themselves but also wants to see at least one frigate saved from the scrapyard, preferably repurposed as a reef or diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful surface combatants with extensive weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions in Fiji have led to instability and international isolation, marked by multiple coups, including one in 1987 by indigenous Fijians overthrowing an Indian-dominated government and another in 2000 led by George Speight, which harmed the economy and international reputation. Persistent tensions culminated in a 2006 military takeover, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. In 2012, Fiji agreed to hold free elections in 2014, restoring diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and re-instatement to the Commonwealth. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep segregation. Fiji's economy, reliant on sugar and tourism, is diverse but hampered by trade and budget deficits, making it a significant recipient of aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is making efforts to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mekdad cited attacks on shipments by terrorist groups as the reason for delays. He defended the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, rejecting US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation, and accused the US of supporting terrorists in Syria. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported ongoing fighting and the release of hundreds of detainees. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 30 tonnes (4%) having been transferred so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan, with a final deadline set for the end of June. Mekdad emphasized Syria's commitment to fulfilling its obligations under the OPCW and UN Security Council agreements.

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 2014 Booker Prize, which includes six novels: Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others," Howard Jacobson's "J," Ali Smith's "How To Be Both," Joshua Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour," Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. The shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a bound edition of their book. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and whose spouse is in the public eye, argues for his right to privacy due to alleged extra-marital activities. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish details of these activities, which involve PJS having "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, AB, and a subsequent three-way encounter with AB and CD. Despite PJS's legal efforts, the Court of Appeal judges ruled that confidentiality had likely been lost due to widespread publication and internet dissemination.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was opened in 1989 and recently purchased for £345.5m. The new owners, Crown Estates, are planning improvements to address parking and traffic congestion issues, as well as enhancing the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, highlighted that Fosse Park serves as a gateway into the city and that the new owners view it as an investment opportunity for improvement. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to improve the quality of common areas and facilities to ensure Fosse Park remains a desirable location.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the release of the live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" in Malaysia, due to the inclusion of a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) initially approved the film with a minor edit to remove the gay moment, but Disney delayed the release for further review. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, leading to debates and criticism from both the public and the country's tourism minister. The film was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification," and the LPF emphasized that their role is limited to content approval, not screening dates or locations. Local cinema chains offered refunds to customers who had purchased tickets in advance. The gay moment in question involves LeFou, the sidekick of the main antagonist Gaston, exploring his feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film sparked significant criticism on social media.

The passage highlights the issue of unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in Southampton, where landlords are required to obtain a licence for properties housing more than three unrelated people. Despite the potential fines of up to £20,000, many landlords are deterred by the £1,000 licensing cost. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan notes that tenants often fear eviction and poor living conditions in unregulated rented homes due to the shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, specific areas have been designated for licensing since 2013 and 2015. The council reports general cooperation from landlords but has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

The passage discusses the efforts of Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil plans to facilitate a minority government but will not support a government program. Water charges are a significant issue; Fianna Fáil wants their immediate removal, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. A commission to consider Irish Water's future is being proposed. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no majority government was formed, and a new Taoiseach has yet to be elected.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire approximately 27km from Mallorca while en route to Valencia. The blaze, which started on one of the car decks, quickly escalated, leading to the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats. At least three people were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt, and were transported to the hospital by helicopter. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, responded to the distress call, with the passengers and crew eventually boarding the Puglia ferry. The rescued individuals were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive shortly. Psychologists were requested to provide counseling at the port. The Balearic Islands port authority stated that The Sorrento may sink due to the fire. The incident began with a distress signal at 13:50 local time, and despite initial assessments that evacuation might not be necessary, the fire's intensity necessitated a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had raised concerns about individuals, including students, allegedly voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The commission suggested that better integration of individual electoral registers could help identify duplicate entries. Despite this, a record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. However, there were concerns over duplicate applications, with estimates suggesting 30-70% of applications in different areas could be duplicates. The commission called for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to systems used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register, especially given the rise in registration and turnout among younger voters.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska and NFL player for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, was found to have killed himself in prison. Phillips had a troubled career and personal life, marked by legal issues including convictions for assaulting a group of teenagers and his former girlfriend. He was serving a more than 30-year sentence and had been accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward. Despite his intelligence and some positive qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted at an event in Chester marking eight years of the regiment. He was awarded the honor by the colonel, Brigadier Andrew Williams, for "good behavior." Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th century. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment upon its formation in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, receives rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. His career highlights include switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage recounts a thrilling football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund, where Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory in injury time, thanks to Dejan Lovren's goal. The match was a pivotal moment in Liverpool's journey under manager Jurgen Klopp, who aimed to "turn doubters into believers." The game was marked by intense emotion, with Liverpool overcoming a 2-0 deficit to score three goals in quick succession, invoking the spirit of their historic 2005 Champions League comeback. Klopp's leadership and the team's resilience were central to the victory, which was celebrated by both players and fans. The match also highlighted the growing stature of young players like Divock Origi and the need for defensive improvements. Overall, the victory brought Liverpool closer to a potential Champions League spot and reinforced Klopp's impact on the team's identity.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, David Davis, and Scottish Government Minister for UK Negotiations on Scotland's Place in Europe, Michael Russell, expressed their views on the ongoing Brexit negotiations. Davis emphasized the UK government's commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about the negotiations and proposed monthly meetings to facilitate a "two-way information flow." He highlighted the importance of collaboration between the UK government and the devolved administrations to secure the best deal for the UK. Russell acknowledged the progress in involving the Scottish government but stressed the need for greater transparency and clarity from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions, particularly on whether the UK will remain in the single market or the customs union. He asserted that single market membership is crucial for Scotland's economic prosperity. The passage also mentions the ongoing legal battle over the triggering of Article 50, with the Scottish government planning to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal.

The passage describes a physical examination of Daisy, a cloned sheep, by veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr. Daisy is part of a flock of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal. Professor Kevin Sinclair, a developmental biologist, explains that these sheep are essentially identical twin sisters to Dolly. The examination aims to detect signs of crepitus, lameness, or other indicators of disease or osteoarthritis. The study's goal is to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy, addressing concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" from adult cells. The research focuses on three age-related diseases: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The study's results, which could impact the future of cloning, are set to be published, and the cloned sheep, now in their ninth and tenth years, appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favorite, after assessing the course, won by a length and three quarters over runner-up Vintage Folly. The horse will race next at Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, and Shutter Speed, who previously beat Enable, secured a fifth Musidora win for Gosden and Dettori. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes and will decide whether to run him in the Derby trial based on the course conditions. Shutter Speed will compete in France's Oaks, and Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet for the Epsom Oaks.

The passage discusses the fluctuations in the British pound's value against major currencies, particularly the dollar and euro, amidst heightened uncertainty leading up to the UK's referendum on EU membership. The pound initially slipped, then recovered, and fell again, mirroring the volatility index levels reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound's decline was merely a return to March levels. Investors were spooked by polls indicating a potential Leave vote, alongside global economic concerns. Hedge funds were betting on further declines in sterling, and markets were on high alert for a potential Brexit. The economic impact of leaving the EU also caused significant drops in Asian stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei index falling 3.5%. Despite these concerns, some argued that a weaker pound could benefit UK exporters.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Despite conceding a goal early in the match after a long journey, manager Cowley praised the team's performance against a strong Barrow team. Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, while Braintree's losing streak reached three games. Cowley remains positive, acknowledging the team's remarkable achievements so far and emphasizing the challenges ahead for the part-time team. He expressed determination to embrace and enjoy the tough journey ahead.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will take over planning decisions from the Planning Service, which currently reports to Stormont's environment department. This shift, effective from April 2015, means that elected politicians will make the final decisions on developments, such as new houses or extensions. Proponents, like Michael Corr of PLACE, see this as an opportunity for councils to develop community and development plans, democratizing the system. However, concerns are raised about the skills of politicians in handling planning issues and the potential for discrimination or favoritism, as seen in the 1960s. Friends of the Earth advocate for strict transparency measures to ensure fairness. Additionally, there are debates about the impact on political donations and the need for greater transparency in this area.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The Scottish SPCA described her as "incredibly lucky" to survive. The incident has renewed calls for the Scottish government to implement licensing for air weapons, a proposal that faced opposition in a previous consultation, with 87% of respondents rejecting the idea. Teenie's owner, Sarah Nisbett, expressed concern about the danger posed to children in the area. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a significant fee, making him their second most expensive acquisition and their seventh summer signing. Benteke, a Belgium international, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. He expressed his excitement to join Liverpool, aiming to win trophies and achieve great goals with the team. Liverpool's attack struggled last season due to the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, leading to the signing of Benteke to bolster their scoring capabilities. Benteke's former manager, Paul Lambert, and former Liverpool striker, John Aldridge, both believe he will excel at Anfield, bringing a strong presence and goal-scoring ability to the team.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, examined the use of tablet devices in 671 state and independent schools, finding that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets to some extent. While there is no definitive evidence of academic improvement, tablets are increasingly prevalent, with 45% of non-users planning to introduce them soon. The study highlights that tablets are particularly popular in academy schools and are seen as motivational tools for disengaged pupils, fostering family involvement when taken home. Additionally, a separate study suggests that touch-screen computers, like tablets, are beneficial for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The widespread use of tablets reflects the integration of technology in young people's lives, with many pupils using devices for social media and entertainment, even at home.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the lives of children in Liverpool over more than 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images provide a social history of the city and highlight changes in children's lives, including special occasions and work. The oldest photo, from 1887, depicts the Rollo siblings in costumes for a fancy dress ball. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes both joyful and challenging aspects of childhood, reflecting on how experiences have evolved. The exhibition runs until September 25.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join a National League rival by mutual consent. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is set to join the Gulls, pending international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's potential. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to be contracted to work with parental authorization. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera explains that this legislation reflects Bolivia's economic needs as one of the poorest countries in South America. The law also imposes a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide and aims to address the issue of child labor, with over 500,000 children already working in various conditions, including extreme ones in mines and agriculture. President Evo Morales, who was absent during the signing, ensured a balance between national reality and international law. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is studying the law to determine if it complies with international child labor regulations, though it acknowledges Bolivia's unique needs.

The passage describes a 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, who experienced a heart attack after searching online for symptoms such as sudden nausea and aches. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell's symptoms began after helping a woman in her Nyack village home. She revealed the type of attack as the "widow maker" and warned readers to recognize symptoms and call emergency services. O'Donnell is an actress known for roles in films and TV shows, and she recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was cancelled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was stabbed during a scuffle in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition at a north London hospital. Police believe Che was not involved in an earlier altercation with youths denied entry to the party but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses a reorganization of cancer diagnosis methods in Denmark, focusing on improving survival rates by addressing long waiting times and vague symptoms. A team from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark, to learn about their approach, which was prompted by "quite alarming" cancer survival statistics showing Denmark lagging behind other European countries. The Danish model of care includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with obvious symptoms, diagnosis centers for those with unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms. This system has improved organization and survival rates, with Denmark catching up to other European countries. The Welsh team found the Danish approach, which emphasizes collaboration between GPs and specialists, to be a valuable model for potential implementation in Wales.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) and the subsequent appointment of Powys Council to take over the responsibility of issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest or law-breaking estate agents. Powys won the competitive bidding process and will receive £170,000 annually for this service. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, which will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro from Powys Council, who will lead the new team, expressed hope that this role will demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The passage discusses a plan approved by NHS Employers to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce, with nurses potentially taking on additional roles traditionally filled by doctors and pharmacists. This move is seen as a response to gaps in junior doctor rotas and the increasing patient load on GPs. The Nuffield Trust review highlighted successful experiments in this direction, noting that the changing nature of care, focusing more on managing long-term conditions, makes such shifts logical. However, unions caution against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems, emphasizing the need for proper training and funding. The British Medical Association and Unison both stress the importance of maintaining high-quality training for doctors and ensuring adequate funding for necessary training courses.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing significant disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, and investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, a local bus service provider, reported that while some services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and understanding during the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the impact of a proposed tidal lagoon on fish populations. NRW estimated that the lagoon could cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually, based on what it considered the "best available evidence." TLP disputed these figures, arguing they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and accused NRW of refusing to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggested a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all fish species. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is seen as a test for larger, more cost-effective versions around the UK coast. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and the Welsh Government is supportive but seeks clarity on the UK's position. NRW defended its figures, stating they were based on extensive evidence and independent assessments.

The passage discusses the announcement by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister, Arlene Foster, about the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, aims to enhance the agri-food industry, which is crucial with nearly 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The initiative is developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and is expected to provide strategic leadership and coordination for marketing activities, benefiting both government and private sectors. Stormont's Agriculture Minister, Michelle O'Neill, supports the move but acknowledges potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and looks forward to discussions with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting the public to participate in planting 40,000 trees. This initiative is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees across four new woods in the UK, commemorating the millions of lives lost during WW1. The project, titled "We will stand for those who fell," aims to create a living tribute to the 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict. The Woodland Trust encourages local residents and visitors to contribute to this historical effort by planting trees, which will serve as a lasting memorial for future generations. The event provides saplings and advises participants to wear appropriate footwear. Brackfield Wood is located seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available for attendees.
