Despite his personal views, Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, showing respect for their decisions. He also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has received significant financial commitments for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are an adventurous couple from Spain and Latvia who embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their trip in London, cycling through 16 countries in 356 days, covering nearly 7,000 miles. They live on a minimal budget, spending less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their only major expense is food, which costs them 2.74 euros each per day. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent.

A Texas couple married in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth snapshots from their event. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, claims they were not aware of the offensive captions until months after the wedding, when the bride's sister informed them. Evans denies the allegations and has not apologized, prompting the couple to file a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The case is set for mediation, with the couple seeking at least an apology from Evans.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, unsure of when he will return to action for Harlequins. He aims to avoid an extended break by not rushing his recovery. Brown's cautious stance is influenced by the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended absences due to concussions. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, has helped Brown recognize when to withdraw from play, as seen in his decision to pull out before a crucial match against Ireland.

A leading expert suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of couples having sex each month. Research indicates that the frequency of sex among Britons has been decreasing since the advent of the internet. A study by Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, reveals that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the increasing integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, which leaves less "quiet empty time" for intimacy. He also notes that the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world has made lives busier, pushing sex lower on the list of priorities.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in popularity and fortune of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once highly prized and could command prices of up to £1.2 million each. The decline is attributed to several factors, including the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which made it less acceptable to give or receive the dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have significantly impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skins for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued groups of these dogs from cramped cages, some of which were already dead or suffering from injuries. The breed's quality has also deteriorated due to unscrupulous breeding practices driven by profit. The passage also mentions that the rapid pace of urbanization in China has made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

The passage highlights a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed claimed to have experienced sexual harassment on public transport. Half of these women reported being assaulted before the age of 18. The survey found that all female users of mass transit have been victims of gender harassment or sexual assault, often unreported and normalized. Harassment ranges from insults to sex attacks, and it affects women's freedom, leading them to alter their daily routines to avoid confrontation. The survey led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport, emphasizing the need for women to recognize and report harassment and for aggressors to understand the legal consequences of their actions.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily stressors identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top concern was not being able to sleep, leading to the design of "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications. Other issues included forgetting to lock the door, solved by the "Forget Me Lock" device, and running out of phone battery, addressed by "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger. These prototypes were created by groups from Makerversity and are now open for public voting on Twitter. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into a real product.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under investigation for allocating £500,000 of public funds to a charity she co-directs, Victims First Northumbria, which supports crime victims in her area. Sitting alongside her on the charity's board is Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics accuse them of creating a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public money. The Ministry of Justice is probing the matter to determine if any conflict of interest rules were breached. Baird defended her decision, stating all procedures were followed, while Sim announced her retirement from the force in June.

Three people, including ringleader Corey Campbell, have been sentenced to prison for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and accused him of stealing money and drugs. The assault took place over three days in a basement in Philadelphia, where Valecce was restrained and subjected to physical abuse and tattooing with offensive symbols. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact police. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, while his girlfriend, Sandra Ng, received 23 months. Another accomplice, Carl Halin, also received a 20-year sentence. Two others, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, who is 21 years old. United manager Louis van Gaal, who is already familiar with Depay's qualities from their time together with the Dutch national team, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, who recently won the Dutch championship. Despite competition from clubs like Paris-Saint Germain, Manchester United appears to be in a strong position to secure Depay's signature.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a third goal. The match saw strong performances from Chelsea's defense, particularly Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, who effectively neutralized City's attack. Manchester City's players, including Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant, showed resilience but struggled against Chelsea's vibrant attack. The match also featured standout performances from Chelsea's midfielders, Charlie Colkett and Ruben Sammut, who controlled the game.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He supports state legislators deciding on gay marriage and does not believe it should be a constitutional right. Despite his personal views, Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, showing respect for their decisions. He also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has received significant financial commitments for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are an adventurous couple from Spain and Latvia who embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their trip in London, cycling through 16 countries in 356 days, covering nearly 7,000 miles. They live on a minimal budget, spending less than three euros each per day, primarily on food, and rely on free accommodation through camping and hosting websites. Their journey has taken them through Europe and into Asia, with plans to continue cycling across the Pacific and the American continent.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, unsure of when he will return to action for Harlequins. He aims to avoid an extended break by not rushing his recovery. Brown's cautious stance is influenced by the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended absences due to concussions. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, has helped Brown recognize when to withdraw from play, as seen when he pulled out of a match against Ireland. Brown emphasizes the importance of honesty about symptoms and the dangers of pushing through them, advocating for teammates to do the same.

A leading expert suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of couples having sex each month. Research indicates that the frequency of sex among Britons has been decreasing since the advent of the internet. A study by Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, reveals that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, which leaves less "quiet empty time" for intimacy. He also notes that technological advancements have blurred the boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, making people busier and reducing the time spent with partners. A researcher adds that with more demands on time, sex becomes a lower priority, and late-night work emails can further distract from focusing on a partner.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in popularity and fortune of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once highly prized and could command prices of up to £1.2 million each. The decline is attributed to several factors, including the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which made it less acceptable to give or receive the dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have significantly impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skins for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued groups of these dogs from cramped cages, many of which were in poor health. The breed's quality has also suffered due to unscrupulous breeding practices, leading to a glut of poor-quality dogs that cannot be sold. The passage also notes that urbanization has made Tibetan Mastiffs less suited to city living, further contributing to their decline.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily stressors identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top concern was not being able to sleep, followed by losing keys and being stuck in traffic. Design groups from Makerversity created prototypes to tackle these issues, with three finalists: 'Snooze,' an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; 'Forget Me Lock,' a device that indicates door lock status; and 'Nipper,' a compact phone charger. The public can vote on Twitter for their favorite, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Other notable designs included a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cyclists and a parking pin that alerts users to free spaces.

Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after the latter was substituted in the 83rd minute during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but later admitted his mistake when Townsend scored a crucial equalizer for England against Italy. Despite this, Merson couldn't resist another dig at Townsend after the Tottenham game, leading to a brief exchange on Twitter.

Chelsea has made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto, a Japan international who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the move to Stamford Bridge is completed. The offer is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if the move is finalized. The potential deal is estimated at £4 million, but Muto has not yet decided whether to join the Premier League club.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics, which are used to fatten farm animals, may also contribute to childhood obesity. The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records. It found that children who had taken antibiotics as infants were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain and slightly taller than those not given antibiotics. The study did not prove a direct cause-and-effect relationship but hypothesized that antibiotics might alter gut bacteria, potentially increasing appetite and contributing to obesity. The findings highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, especially given the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an event witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was caught on camera, left the guard embarrassed as he lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle. Despite the mishap, he quickly recovered and continued his duties, though he appeared visibly embarrassed. The event is a popular tourist attraction, with guards being fully operational soldiers, not purely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The classic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016. The new version, to be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, will focus on the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake, which aims to be both original and contemporary, drawing more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." The production will consult with scholars for historical authenticity. The remake aims to resonate with a new generation of viewers, considering recent events such as Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar-winning film "12 Years a Slave," as well as ongoing racial issues in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has claimed that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978, on his first day of work. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, said he was accosted in a bedroom by several men, one of whom was a senior staff member. He was pinned to a chair and groped, leading him to leave the job immediately. Lawler, now 64, contacted palace officials again last year after inquiries into alleged child sex abuse cover-ups by a VIP paedophile ring. His complaints were initially ignored, but the police were eventually notified. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was interviewed but denied involvement, claiming he was working elsewhere at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with any police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The Meeks revealed the news after initially lying about not being ready for parenthood, and the video includes a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple found the video's success unexpected and plan to make another video after learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. The dress, originally slate blue-gray but faded to light gray, was worn in key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and during an attack in a shanty town. The collection belonged to James Tumblin, who acquired the dress for $20 in the 1960s and had amassed over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. The boy suffered minor bumps and bruises and was in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach the child, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

The passage discusses a speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which has been re-angled to point directly at a house's front door. The camera, originally enforcing a 30mph speed limit on the residential road, has been non-functional for over two years due to the decommissioning of all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands in March 2013, as their technology became obsolete. Instead, speed enforcement is now handled by mobile camera units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers. The re-angling of the camera remains a mystery, but Birmingham City Council is aware and will send an engineer to assess the situation, potentially removing the camera. The council is developing a pilot program using digital technology for a limited number of sites but has no plans to include the Wellington Road camera in this initiative.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete as part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his excitement to be part of the team and his readiness to perform, highlighting Jamaica's strong tradition in relays. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) expressed delight at Bolt's availability and anticipated a strong performance from him. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, both teammates at Barcelona, demonstrated their support for the club's basketball side by attending an El Clasico match on Thursday night, where Barcelona won 85-80 in the Euro League. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division due to a points difference. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile in a challenging match, and he and his Barcelona teammates are set to return to La Liga action against Celta Vigo, aiming to continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. There has been a recent surge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean, with Italy registering over 10,000 arrivals in the first three months of 2015. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason for Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, a Chilean forward, was courted by several elite clubs after leaving Barcelona but ultimately chose Arsenal, where he has made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger also praised Sanchez's quick adaptation to the new environment, highlighting his qualities as top-tier. Additionally, Wenger downplayed any speculation about a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, expressing admiration for Brendan Rodgers' management of Liverpool despite the sale of Suarez and injuries to key players.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes and hopes for a capacity crowd to support his attempt. Tickets for the event, which will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, go on sale from April 19. Wiggins' attempt is part of his return to the track, with a goal of achieving a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, described her struggle to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday as an 'eye-opener' for the claycourt season. Despite prevailing 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams acknowledged her unpreparedness for clay courts. The US team was relegated to World Group II after losing the doubles rubber 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. Williams emphasized the need to adapt her game for clay, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez highlighted the team's need to work harder to return to the elite group.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine side from 2001 to 2009. Falcao, who has struggled during his loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, may return to his parent club Monaco or join River Plate. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the team's desire to bring Falcao back, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao has recently shown good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games, tying the national team's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his time at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Pop star Ella Henderson, known for her impressive vocals on The X Factor in 2012, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop, showcasing her versatility. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, noting her regular use of the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste, anticipating a successful 2015 for the partnership.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14, was erected in Kenosham, Wisconsin, causing shock among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal. The police association claims no offense was intended and that the billboard was meant to express gratitude for community support. Torres is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into Siler's death. This incident follows another shooting by Torres, where he wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. Both shootings are under investigation.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. Three militants were also killed by Iranian forces in the fighting in the town of Negur. The militants, who crossed into Iran from Pakistan, are believed to be part of the Jaish al Adal group, which has targeted Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving assailants. Pakistan condemned the attack and is investigating the incident, promising to apprehend and bring to justice any militants who fled back into Pakistan.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan regarding the possibility of extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered any UFOs from outer space. This revelation came in response to a question from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history of interest in UFOs and mixed-discipline matches. Inoki, known for his unique political and entertainment career, asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. This exchange reflects a broader interest in the implications of extraterrestrial visitors, as seen in previous discussions by Japanese politicians.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after he broke a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. Jin had stood on the toilet's rim, concerned about cleanliness, when it collapsed, causing severe injuries. He was found bleeding and was taken to a hospital, where he received dozens of stitches. Initially, Jin confessed to squatting on the toilet but later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident, and a police spokesman reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over a four-year period and filming her and others using a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse began when the girl was nine and continued until she was 13. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation started when the girl discovered a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had specifically purchased the camera to record the girl while she undressed and showered. The preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and Rebbie is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of portraits featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their teenage daughters, aiming to capture a more dynamic and expressive side of the typically serious father-daughter relationship. The images, part of Aoyama's latest book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," show daughters smiling directly at the camera while their fathers perform energetic jumps, often in sharp suits. The series has garnered significant online interest for its unique and curious nature, despite limited information about its origins.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and its potential impact on Kevin Pietersen's chances of returning to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is seen in a reflective mood during a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval before the start of the County Championship season. The event marks a step closer to a possible return to the international set-up for Pietersen, who last played for England during a disastrous Ashes tour in Australia in 2013-14. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test team, with Surrey set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender, was initially fired after a poor run but was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was fired again. The club is now 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who had 25 caps for Brazil, replaced Florin Marin in January and will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, a former Monaco teammate of Radamel Falcao, believes the Colombian striker regrets his loan move to Manchester United despite being unhappy in France. Falcao, who previously played for Atletico Madrid, joined Manchester United on a season-long loan but has struggled to perform at the same level since a serious knee injury. With only four goals scored this season, Manchester United is unlikely to make his transfer permanent, which would cost £46 million. Dirar suggests that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League and felt more comfortable.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The offender, captured on security footage, made off with the dairy's till and approximately $1500 in cash. The robbery occurred on Saturday when the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop screaming. The police were called to the scene but found no signs of weapons. The robber remains at large, and authorities urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for alleged inappropriate relationships with underage students. In March, she was arrested for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. Subsequently, another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The Irving school district has taken immediate action, placing her on administrative leave to prevent her from interacting with students.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has gone viral, garnering over half a million views. The crocodile, which was seen near a sanctuary 200 meters away, held onto the dog for hours. The dog, belonging to the local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge, likely out of curiosity, but was quickly seized by the crocodile. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the incident while on holiday with his wife, described the scene as a "shock to the system." Social media reactions to the video were mixed, with some expressing horror and others noting the common presence of crocodiles in the area due to its mangrove ecosystem.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, leaving them just two points clear of the drop zone. Bruce initially aimed for 10 wins to survive but now hopes 'nine or eight might be enough.' Hull has six games remaining, including challenging fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, but remains optimistic about avoiding relegation. Southampton, meanwhile, moved to fifth in the table after the win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty designated for James Ward-Prowse.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the entire school's SATs results. Guffick, who worked at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, asked pupils to modify their answers after the exam session had finished. He also altered some answers himself. This led to an investigation by the local education authority, which resulted in the Department for Education annulling all SATs results for the school. Guffick admitted his actions and accepted they amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. Despite his claim that he only asked pupils to make answers more legible, a panel ruled that no changes should be made outside exam conditions. Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years and had 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has struggled for playing time but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard, who joined Manchester United in 2010 from Aalesunds, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his limited on-pitch success, Lindegaard remains content in his personal life with Beqiri, who frequently shares modeling photos on Instagram.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson, failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction, despite expectations of $300,000 to $600,000. Jackson, who bought the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, hoped a new generation would own and enjoy the iconic signage. The letters, installed in 1976, were taken down in 2008. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional conduct after recent incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Despite these issues, neither player will face disciplinary action, and Rodgers aims to move past the incidents. Rodgers is focused on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after a suspension. He emphasizes the importance of learning from setbacks and using them as a part of the journey towards success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, posted a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing with his dog after returning to London following the international break. He had a successful match with Germany, helping them beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who was signed for £42.5 million from Real Madrid in 2013, missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Despite rumors of his activities during his absence, Ozil has been performing well since his return from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He claims to be adjusting well to English football, enjoying the frequent matches and the lack of winter breaks.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has affirmed that there are no plans to replace current manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title with only six games remaining. Bartomeu dismissed speculation about Enrique's potential replacement, highlighting the manager's impressive work, particularly in preparing for crucial matches. The club is content with Enrique's tenure, as Barcelona remains in contention for three major trophies. In a recent match, Enrique's team defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth around £100,000-a-week, which will run until 2020. This follows Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat, and Henderson's current contract had 14 months remaining. The 24-year-old midfielder, signed by Kenny Dalglish in 2011 for £16 million from Sunderland, has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers and has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season. Henderson is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back for Chelsea, has expressed his desire to remain with the club until the end of his contract, despite interest from his former team, Atletico Madrid. He signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July but has faced challenges in securing the left back position. Despite Atletico's hopes of leveraging his situation, Luis remains committed to Chelsea. He recently played for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile, but his focus now shifts to the Premier League title race. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizes the importance of focus and winning every game, with nine challenging matches remaining. Luis believes the team is prepared to handle the pressure and challenges ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a rugby player, had his ban for accidentally injuring George North overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for three matches, Hughes was deemed 'reckless' for his knee colliding with North's head during a try. The red card issued to Hughes was rescinded, and the ban was thrown out after Wasps' appeal, acknowledging the incident was accidental. North, who had been knocked out, was advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms. Hughes missed a Champions Cup match but is now free to return to action, though not immediately in the next game.

A fiery sunset in Washington was caused by raging wildfires in Siberia, which started from farmers burning grass in their fields but quickly spread due to strong winds. The smoke from these fires traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting areas like Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color of the sunset was due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange hues to penetrate unfiltered, especially during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. After a month, her car was found by the police, thanks to a tip from a man named Mick Sexton, but it had been modified with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig embraced the changes and posted a humorous message on Facebook, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is now getting the car professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana left behind. To honor Sexton, Schoenig is creating a special smoothie called "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players, including stars like Sergio Aguero and Yaya Toure, could lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. Their contracts are incentivized to ensure the club stays within financial fairplay rules. Currently in fourth place, City's European hopes are in jeopardy after a loss to Manchester United in the derby, leaving them just four points ahead of Liverpool. The top three Premier League finishers automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The entire squad has around £12 million at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has underperformed this season, losing seven times and exiting early from the FA Cup and Champions League. City faces a challenging run of matches and a potential struggle to attract top talent like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is also of interest to Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s secured a 1-0 victory over Manchester City in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring a delightful free-kick. The match featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were Mancunian, and was free to attend, attracting close to 1,000 spectators. United manager Paul McGuinness aimed to provide his young players with an experience closer to senior football, using a formation similar to the first team. The result left United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased promising talents on both sides, highlighting the potential for future first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who himself reached a milestone of 50 caps, called Buffon an inspiration and expressed his admiration for the veteran's performance at 37 years old. Hart emphasized his own desire to continue learning and playing well for both his club and country, aiming to add more caps to his total.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant chain, has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities. This move includes a 9% service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. Chipotle previously declined collaborations with third-party delivery services but has now approved Postmates, which operates using independent contractors. The chain is not alone in targeting the delivery market; Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services. Chipotle has seen increased popularity, with presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton recently spotted dining at its outlets.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the bombings. In an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard described the profound impact the tragedy had on their family, including the death of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter. They argue that pursuing the death penalty could lead to years of appeals and further trauma for their family and the community. Instead, they propose that Tsarnaev should spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release or appeal. The Richards emphasize that their stance is personal and aimed at ending the ongoing anguish for their family and the broader community.

The passage describes an extraordinary custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire. The aircraft, which typically carries up to 600 passengers, was customized over three years at a cost of £400 million to meet the tycoon's specific requirements. The interior features multiple lounges, a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a state room, and an aeroloft with eight full beds. The master bedroom includes a large bed, armchair, and sofa. The plane also boasts a conference room, an office or guest bedroom, and a lounge designed to resemble a luxury hotel. The central portion of the aircraft houses a dining room connected to a kitchen, allowing for the services of a private chef. The luxurious interior is designed to accommodate dozens of guests, offering a level of comfort far beyond that of a typical commercial flight.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. However, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket tipping over after a hard landing. SpaceX aims to reduce space travel costs by reusing rockets, similar to airplanes. The smaller, top part of the rocket will carry the Dragon into orbit before burning up in Earth's atmosphere. The Dragon will dock with the ISS to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, and will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash. This was the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS and the second attempt for this specific mission, after a weather-related scrub on the previous day.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel, located inside the Westgate Hotel, is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home. Priscilla collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the "ultimate wedding," which includes a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. The winning couple will be announced next Monday and will marry on April 23. Priscilla emphasized that the chapel is "first-class" and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. Couples interested in the contest must submit a video or photos along with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, marking his 47th game of the season, a record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Henderson thinks Liverpool, currently four points behind City, can pressure their rivals after recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored in the match, with Allen's goal being his first at Anfield. Despite a potential penalty claim for Newcastle, Liverpool secured a vital win, with Henderson emphasizing the importance of continuing to win games to close the gap on City.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, a crucial match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to secure the win. Roma moved four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who played later, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches. Security was tight due to previous incidents, but the match passed without major issues. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic's early impact and de Sanctis's performance were pivotal.

The passage describes a dull and uneventful match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town in League One, which ended in a 0-0 draw. The match was so lackluster that Doncaster's media team struggled to compile highlights, resulting in a 27-second video featuring only the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. This highlights the season's mediocrity for Doncaster Rovers and the challenges faced by the media team in presenting the match.

The passage describes a unique relationship between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986. Despite the common belief that marine pets lack the ability to interact through touch, Giroux has developed a remarkable bond with his fish, which he captures on video. The fish, initially shy, eventually becomes comfortable with Giroux's touch, allowing him to stroke and massage it. This interaction began when Giroux noticed the fish being bullied by its tank mates and removed them, subsequently feeding the fish by hand and noticing its increasing sociability. The fish now enjoys daily massages and becomes frustrated if not interacted with. The video shows the fish swimming around Giroux's fingers and following his hand even when removed from the tank, demonstrating a deep attachment.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team, highlighting his fiery character and the need for careful management to channel his aggression positively. Stokes' reputation for being feisty and his ability to handle confrontations, such as his clash with Marlon Samuels, are noted. The importance of maintaining his natural exuberance while controlling his aggression is emphasized, as it contributes to his performance in bringing runs and wickets to the team. The passage also mentions the potential inclusion of a second spinner, Adil Rashid, and the desire to see Stokes and Chris Jordan develop further in the international game. Overall, the text underscores the balance required in managing Stokes' temperament to maximize his contribution to the team.

The passage highlights that Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier match against Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both Wales and Belgium are leading Group B with 11 points each, but Belgium is ahead due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has heightened expectations for their qualification to the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales (FAW) reported overwhelming ticket demand, leading to the sell-out. The Wales squad reportedly prefers the Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium, where they haven't played since 2011, due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the match.

England coach John Peacock has selected his squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The Young Lions, defending champions after winning last year's final against Holland on penalties, qualified for this edition with a perfect record. They are grouped with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D and will start against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, the latter being called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled after missing the Elite Round qualifiers, where England secured their place in the finals by defeating Romania, Norway, and Slovenia. The team's other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth system. He has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 due to his family's desire for him to continue his studies. City has held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation package, aiming to secure Patoulidis for their future.

A man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, who was found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. The 23-year-old suspect has been bailed and is due to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and her profession may be central to the investigation.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to accuse her long-term friend, Jamie, of stealing £207 that was set aside for a gravestone for her baby. Jamie, a convicted burglar, lived with Dawn and her partner, also named Jamie. After a lie detector test conducted by Jeremy Kyle revealed that Jamie had indeed taken the money, Dawn was devastated and stormed off the stage. Jamie later confessed to taking the money in a Facebook message but blamed his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn expressed deep distress and betrayal, as the money was meant to honor her lost child, Daniel James.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group persecuted by the terror organization, in northern Iraq. Most of those released were women and children, with some being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, and the freed Yazidis were taken to Irbil by Peshmerga forces. The motivation behind the release remains unclear. This is part of a series of releases by ISIS since their attacks on Yazidi towns last year, which led to widespread displacement and persecution of the Yazidis.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team and the England national side, and is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animated video produced by Copa90 features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', has been released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane is competing against Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite the team's recent lack of trophies and potential failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on one season and that the team's new players have yet to fully integrate. He emphasizes the importance of making the right signings to improve the team. Carragher also highlights his community work in Merseyside, receiving a Beacon Award for his efforts through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in schools in deprived areas. He hopes his work can inspire young people in the community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. Despite being a brightly colored, plastic Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, airport security deemed it a risk and forced James to hand it over. His father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and described the staff as "over-zealous." The airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, stating that their priority is passenger safety and security, and that all regulations are set by the government. The hand luggage restrictions, set by the Department of Transport, include a ban on items that resemble prohibited items, such as replica or model guns. After returning from their holiday in Lanzarote, James was given a replacement toy gun.

A man named Rich, living in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. His requirements for the ideal partner include loving pets, being a non-drinker and smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at household tasks, cooking, and in bed. The successful candidate would receive benefits such as a gym membership, a phone, and possibly a company car, laptop, and accommodation. Rich described himself as athletic, tattooed, a non-drinker and smoker, and successful with his own properties and a love for the outdoors, sports, and travel. He promised to provide various benefits and stated that all reasonable offers would be considered, though former partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia attempted to contact Rich but was unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement radical changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12, with the definition of 'home-grown' changing to players trained in England for three years before the age of 18. Dyke faces opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—have backed Dyke's proposals, warning that blocking these changes could hinder England's chances of winning the World Cup. They emphasize the importance of providing opportunities for young English talent, citing the emergence of players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane as evidence of potential.

In the latest episode of the show, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby daughter, much to the delight of her husband, Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner. Despite Ross marrying Demelza out of duty, he expresses deep affection for her, stating she makes him a better man. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is notably rushed, with the previous episode ending with the announcement of her pregnancy, and the current episode beginning with her already eight months pregnant, followed shortly by the birth. This rapid progression has been a point of humor among fans, who have noted the show's tendency to quickly advance pregnancy timelines.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. The Foxes, currently bottom of the Barclays Premier League but with a slim chance of survival after back-to-back wins, are three points from safety. Pearson emphasized that their future is in their own hands and that they must concentrate on their remaining games to give themselves a realistic chance of staying in the league. He warned against being overly optimistic and stressed the importance of maintaining focus on their own performance.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's migration, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale. This discovery could impact the understanding of the genetic differentiation between the species and the conservation efforts for western gray whales, of which only about 150 are believed to exist.

In the morning, residents on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island discovered that 1,000ft of seabed had risen to the surface overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu. The landmass, which rose as high as 50ft in some places, exposed the ocean floor and measures approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Geologists attribute this phenomenon to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area into the air. Local residents were surprised by the sudden appearance of the landmass, as there were no indications of movement or tremors overnight. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and believe it is unrelated to recent earthquakes.

Dutch footballer Gregory van der Wiel has refuted claims of his impending departure from Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, emphasizing his happiness and commitment to the club. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc, who dropped him from a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel expressed his love for PSG, the city, and his teammates, stating there is no reason for him to leave. He also mentioned his desire to sign a new contract. However, PSG's potential interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could influence Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, the former Manchester City striker currently with Juventus, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer and return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus running until the end of the 2015-2016 season, Tevez has reportedly informed the club of his intention to depart. Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old, but Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez, who is on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus and still has a chance at European glory, has always stated his intention to finish his career at Boca Juniors. Juventus, while reluctant to lose their top scorer, has accepted Tevez's decision and is already looking for potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, has stated that any move would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team, emphasizing that Tevez's performance is the most important factor.

In a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich, led by manager Pep Guardiola, achieved a 6-1 victory over Porto, securing their place in the semi-finals. The match was marked by an exciting first half where Bayern led 5-0. During the match, Guardiola accidentally tore a hole in his trousers, revealing his underwear, an incident he humorously addressed after the game. Despite Porto's initial two-goal lead from their previous match, Bayern's impressive performance demonstrated their superiority, leaving their European rivals concerned.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in various injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, while a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also flown out for treatment. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped person. The highway remained closed for a few hours.

The passage highlights the upcoming Premier League match between second-placed Arsenal and leaders Chelsea, with Arsenal's Mesut Ozil eagerly anticipating the game. Ozil recently acquired an Apple Watch, which he compared to a watch from the TV show Knight Rider, and is expected to start for Arsenal. The team trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining but has been bolstered by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench for their FA Cup semi-final win. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be a key player for Arsenal if he can maintain fitness, noting his injury history as a concern.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite past controversies and having sent off three players from both teams this season, Clattenburg is considered one of the Premier League's leading referees. Notably, he has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to Manchester United players: Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. The derby is crucial as it could determine who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea, with United currently leading City by a point. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of viewing embattled MP Billy Gordon as 'a little black puppet on a string,' suggesting a racial bias. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, has faced racist attitudes himself and sympathizes with Gordon. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party due to domestic violence accusations and undisclosed criminal history, but plans to remain as an independent MP, causing political turmoil. Katter's statement sparked criticism, but he defended his use of the term 'black puppet,' drawing parallels to his own experiences and those of other independent MPs who have been seen as government puppets.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who has cerebral palsy, is using her passion for dancing to inspire others and challenge stereotypes associated with disabilities. Despite facing bullying and judgment, Dayna creates videos to show that she is capable of doing many things, just differently. Her goal is to change how people with disabilities are represented in media and fashion, encouraging others to think before judging. Dayna has produced several videos, including one dancing to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has started motivational speaking at local schools to share her story and inspire others.

Orlando City, an MLS side, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled on loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexican international, would be a significant commercial asset for Orlando City, which has a large Latin-American fanbase and is coached by Adrian Heath. Eight European clubs are also interested in Hernandez, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for around £8 million. Additionally, United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three individuals poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday, setting the vehicle on fire. The driver had an argument with the suspects while pumping gas, and the group attempted to carjack him before lighting the car ablaze with two passengers inside. No injuries were reported, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being used in the ongoing investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges against Manuel, who admitted to his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these allegations, Manuel received outstanding patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state. These circumstances included bartering sex for services and advising patients to stop taking prescribed medication. Manuel's practice was located in Lamoni, a small agricultural town in southern Iowa.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner," prompting the U.S. to complain to Moscow. The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew alleging aggressive maneuvers by the Russian pilot. Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off while approaching the Russian border, a claim denied by the U.S. This is not the first such incident; a similar encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk, leading to U.S. complaints. Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently encounter each other in various regions.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from a Marriott Springhill Suites hotel parking lot in Salt Lake City. The rifle, secured in a hard case and locked to a truck safe, was taken by breaking the car's rear right passenger-side window and using a rope or cable lock to pull the case free. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. Along with the rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Some of the stolen items were later found at a Residence Inn across the street, but the sniper rifle remains unrecovered. The hotel, located near the city's airport and the state's FBI office, lacks surveillance cameras. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified of the theft before the president's visit.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, was accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in Red Hill, Canberra. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times in the dining room of his home. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and believed there was evidence of his mental state declining due to dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused state during the incident. Mullen noted that Costa's mood fluctuated during the attack, as evidenced by triple 0 calls he made, and the trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet suggested his confused mental state. The prosecutor suggested that Costa might have feigned memory loss, but Mullen denied this. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as a not guilty verdict can be returned if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

In a recent match, Everton's Ross Barkley missed a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley at Goodison Park, despite the presence of Leighton Baines, who has a high success rate in penalties. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision to take the penalty, stating that he was within his rights to do so and that the team has multiple penalty takers. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton, but the miss did not affect the outcome of the game, as Kevin Mirallas scored the winning goal later.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, with initial indications pointing to a murder-suicide. The cruise line, Holland America Line, secured the cabin and notified authorities, including the FBI. The ship, which departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The deceased passengers were discovered by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door. The FBI is investigating the incident.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert led Curacao to a successful start in World Cup qualifying, advancing to the second round of CONCACAF's 2018 tournament. Curacao won 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second leg against Montserrat. Kluivert's team secured their progress with a 2-1 victory in Willemstad. Charlton Vicento, a former Holland Under 21 international, scored the decisive goal in the 87th minute, ensuring Curacao avoided extra time. They will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has Curacao heritage, previously served as an assistant to Louis van Gaal and was a World Cup semi-finalist in 1998.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan and Real Madrid midfielder, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning major trophies in his career. Leicester City is currently at the bottom of the table, seven points adrift with eight games remaining. Cambiasso, who has won 15 trophies during his time at Inter Milan, including the Champions League and FIFA Club World Cup, is determined to help Leicester avoid relegation. He views this challenge as another "cup" to win and is optimistic about their chances despite their recent struggles. Cambiasso signed for Leicester in the summer on a one-year deal and has become a key player, though his future beyond this season remains uncertain. He is content with his current situation in the East Midlands and hopes to secure more points to aid Leicester's survival.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, faces being banned from seeing her two children under five by her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, due to her persistent drinking, partying, and suspected drug use, particularly with legal high MKat. Debbie stepped in to care for the children after social services threatened to intervene. Debbie accuses Gemma of stealing an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle and admits that Gemma has a history of stealing from her. Gemma's behavior, which includes underage drinking and sex from the age of 13, has led Debbie to conclude that Gemma is unfit to care for her children. Debbie is now preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children, as she cannot trust her not to steal from them.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Eden Hazard scored the opening goal for Chelsea, leading to a 1-0 victory. However, the Sky Sports punditry team, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, believed that the goal should not have stood due to a foul in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry had made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, causing him to fall and lose possession. This led to a loose ball being picked up by Cesc Fabregas, who initiated the scoring move that ended with Hazard's goal. The pundits argued that Terry's rough tackle on Falcao should have resulted in a foul, with Souness describing it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry expressing sympathy for Falcao as a fellow striker. Redknapp also agreed that Terry's challenge from behind should have been penalized, though he acknowledged that Falcao could have been stronger to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire was captured on video by Michael Barnett and occurred after a rear tire blew out. The bus's back lounge was destroyed, except for Scott's Bible. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is exploring the use of space lasers to convert sunlight into energy for heating homes. His project involves satellites orbiting Earth, equipped with mirrors to capture sunlight and convert it into laser light, which is then transmitted back to Earth to power solar panels. This technology could make solar power more viable in regions like Scotland and provide instant energy restoration in disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further trials are planned in Portugal. Unlike fictional depictions, these lasers are not powerful enough to be used as weapons, nor are they intended for tasks like clearing space debris. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the potential security concerns regarding who controls the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offenses involving young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. Munden, who has learning difficulties and a "fanatical obsession" with small girls, was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, at 6.15pm on Tuesday. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. Police have launched a manhunt to locate him, and he is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair. Munden may have shaved off his beard before leaving the hospital, and officers have released images of him with and without facial hair.

The passage details a legal case involving V. Stiviano, who was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from Donald Sterling, the former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers. These gifts, which included luxury cars and other expensive items, were the subject of a lawsuit filed by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who accused Stiviano of exploiting her husband. Stiviano argued that the gifts were legitimate and not taken advantage of. The court's decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family, setting a precedent that allows an injured spouse to recover damages from the recipient of ill-gotten gifts. The case also highlights the controversy surrounding Donald Sterling's racist remarks, which led to his ban from the NBA and the loss of his team.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer window activity and suggested that the club needs to acquire four key players—a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker—to have a chance at winning the Premier League title. Henry specifically questioned whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as the first-choice striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. He cited Chelsea's success in signing players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of how significant signings can impact a team's title chances. Arsenal is currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman has recounted in court the severe impact of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the former boss of Bega Cheese, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who kept the abuse a secret for years, broke her silence after learning Van Ryn had been caught. She expressed fear for her future relationships and confusion about why she was targeted. Van Ryn sat calmly during her testimony, which detailed the profound emotional and psychological effects of the abuse, including depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering from a serious knee injury that kept him out for over a year. He last played in March 2014 during the Champions League against Bayern Munich. Gnabry recently played a full 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s against Reading, indicating his return to fitness. He expressed feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to future games.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, accidentally fell to his death from a 70ft cliff after attempting to avoid paying a taxi fare in Penarth, South Wales. Phillips, who had been out drinking with friends in Cardiff, ran from the taxi driver in the dark and jumped over a fence, unaware of the cliff's edge. He was found dead the next morning by a dog walker on the rocky beach at the base of the cliff. The coroner concluded that Phillips likely became disoriented and did not realize the danger he was in, ruling the death as accidental.
