Neighbors believe the stress of his ongoing divorce may have contributed to the incident. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet disclosed how Sandra was killed. Michael was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, which bypassed the usual bidding process due to what it perceived as a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. However, a recent presentation to the IAAF convinced the governing body that Eugene is capable of staging the championships. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, emphasized that this decision was strategic, involving collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. This decision mirrors the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, which was also awarded without a bidding process.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, 25, has been jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after setting a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in order to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan at a London casino, where he showered her with gifts and cash. She left his flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to tie up and kick Hassan to death while searching for his hidden winnings. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas has struggled during the second half of the season, particularly in Spain's 2-0 defeat by the Netherlands. His form has significantly dipped since Christmas, when he appeared likely to break the Premier League record for assists. Despite his happiness at Chelsea, the 27-year-old's performance has declined, raising questions about his durability. Fabregas' former club, Barcelona, noted a traditional post-Christmas slump in his performance. Although he had 15 assists by mid-January, he has managed only one in five games since, and four in 15 appearances in 2015. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be looking for a late-season resurgence from Fabregas to help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham United is in talks to sign Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, after he impressed during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who has also attracted interest from Belgian clubs, is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, aiming for the cheapest pricing strategy in the Premier League to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium when they move for the 2016-17 season.

The police have halted an investigation into a severe assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite substantial evidence pointing to the identity of the suspected attacker. Lane, who was attacked by masked protesters armed with iron bars, criticized the police decision as "pathetic." A video and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, were provided to Wiltshire Police. The attack occurred during a hunt using an artificial scent, not a fox. Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Wiltshire Police issued the suspect's photograph but have not identified him. The police have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, disappointing hunt supporters. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to aid in identifying criminals.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent member of Al Qaeda who served as the organization's chief English-language propagandist. Born in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1998. Gadahn rose through the ranks in Pakistan, appearing in numerous Al Qaeda videos threatening attacks on the U.S. and other Western targets. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda and was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." Gadahn was killed in January 2015 in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted. His death was announced by the White House in March 2015.

The passage highlights the rise of a five-year-old Chinese basketball prodigy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been shooting hoops since the age of two and a half. A viral video showcasing his impressive skills, including dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm, has garnered him a large fan base in basketball-mad China. This phenomenon has drawn comparisons to the country's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming, and has left many netizens in awe, with some questioning the authenticity of the video and others expressing embarrassment over their own basketball abilities in comparison to Mai's.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lobby for lowering the age of sexual consent to ten, among other goals. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25, chaired by comedian John Cleese, to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, seeks to replace the Independent Press Standards Organisation with a statutory body, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is expected to be an embarrassment for the group.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unconventional catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event showcased a capsule collection of ten unisex pieces by the label "Ten Pieces," designed to be worn in 20 different ways and suitable for day to night wear. The presentation featured monochrome creations, with models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall, set against the backdrop of the ocean. Guests enjoyed nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria, while experiencing the show on a warm, 28-degree Celsius day. The event attracted attention from beachgoers and passers-by who stopped to watch from the road above the pool.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. He was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. Earlier this week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about potential bouts with British rival Kell Brook and others.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was mistakenly included on an Israeli memorial wall commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His name was added at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, a national cemetery, ahead of Israel's Memorial Day. Abu Khdeir, 16, was killed in July by three Israelis, according to prosecutors. His family objected to his inclusion, and Almagor, an organization representing terror victims, described his death as a rogue attack, not terrorism. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name from the memorial.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son attempting to use the family cat's belly as a pillow for rest. The footage shows the boy chasing the cat around the garden, trying to lie on its belly. Each time the boy lies down, the cat quickly moves to another spot, leading to a repeated sequence. Eventually, the cat leaves the garden, but a later video shows the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

The passage details the ongoing police corruption trial in Philadelphia, where witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, has lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, who had passed a background check when hired in 2010, told jurors that undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. He also acknowledged subsequent arrests and convictions, including one for driving under the influence in 2008 and another in 2011, for which he received four years of probation. Kushner expressed regret for his past actions and a desire to move forward, maintaining his innocence regarding the 2011 charges. The defense for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering claims the government's case is built on the testimony of 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, which caused a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, and five of the injured were treated for glass-related injuries. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire, which is now under control. The plant had previously experienced an explosion in 2013 with no reported casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has historically sparked protests in China, leading to the relocation of the Zhangzhou plant from Xiamen in 2007 due to public opposition over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low above his shinpads, a practice he attributes to superstition. Despite being advised by Premier League referees to pull his socks up, Grealish insists on maintaining this habit. He made his first Premier League start on Tuesday night and was pleased with the opportunity, despite the challenging circumstances of the game against QPR. Grealish also revealed that he uses children's shinpads, which he is not planning to change.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with "global and irreversible brain damage." Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed sadness over the possibility of her living in this condition for a lifetime and hopes for a miracle. Bobbi Kristina does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy. Reports of her condition contrast with her father Bobby Brown's statement that she is awake and watching him. An attorney for the family clarified that while her condition has improved, the quality of her life remains uncertain as she begins a long and difficult rehabilitation process.

Russia is leading 2-0 in the Fed Cup tie against Germany, with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saving a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Svetlana Kuznetsova earlier beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's power and had 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were crucial. Russia needs one more win on Sunday to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the system that caused extensive damage last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hinder ongoing cleanup efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still pending from last week's 24,196 requests. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which suffered severe flooding and high winds during the previous storm. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott suggests that the upcoming storm will be less severe than last week's, with rain expected for two days rather than three. The Bureau of Meteorology advises that the main impacts will likely be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, has denied attempting suicide, clarifying that she was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media had reported that she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment. Moric posted photos of her injuries on Instagram, refuting the claims and stating she was recovering at home after a domestic accident. Italian media also claimed she attempted suicide in 2009, which she denied. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzi photographer who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

The passage discusses the British public's preferences for the name of Prince William and Kate Middleton's second child. A recent poll revealed that "Diana" is the favorite name if the baby is a girl, with 12% of respondents suggesting this name in honor of William's late mother, Diana, Princess of Wales. Other popular girl names include "Alice" and "Charlotte," with 9% of the vote each. For a boy, "James" is the preferred name, followed by "Alexander." The public is largely hoping for a baby princess, with 25% of those polled wishing for a daughter, compared to only 3% hoping for a son. Additionally, the majority of Britons support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed it. The protesters were on their way to join a rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back has had a successful seven-year stint at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, at 31 years old, he has been unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves turned down a three-year contract extension that required him to play in 60% of matches, stating that the negotiations are over.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old footballer currently playing for Boca Juniors, has suggested that Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti should join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that both players, known for their South American style of play, would be a perfect fit for Boca Juniors and that the fans would adore them. Pirlo is renowned as one of the best midfielders in the world, while Totti is a Roma legend, and Osvaldo feels Totti would be equally beloved if he moved to Argentina.

The passage describes the incident involving 18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, who became an internet sensation after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. Despite the fall, Ferguson only sustained a cut on his nose and was back to mucking out stables the next day. He remains undeterred from continuing his career as a jockey, despite the attention and light-hearted banter from his peers. The fall has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online.

The passage discusses James Haskell's involvement with the release of the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron." Haskell, a London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram, joining the hype surrounding the movie's premiere at Westfield London shopping centre. Haskell's career includes stints in France, Japan, and New Zealand before returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since surpassed 100 appearances and become a significant part of the England squad.

The passage discusses the resurgence of the wide-leg trouser as a key trend for SS15, offering an alternative to the long-dominant skinny jean. It highlights the versatility of wide-leg trousers, which can be denim, cropped, printed, or striped, and emphasizes the importance of proportion and footwear in making the style work, particularly for shorter individuals. High heels and simple tops are recommended to balance the look. The trend has been seen on various catwalks, including Gucci and Celine, and is available on the high street, such as Topshop's Miller jean. The wide-leg trouser is praised for its ability to update one's wardrobe without requiring good weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students who signed a petition against it. The movie, which portrays the Iraq War and features Bradley Cooper as Navy SEAL Chris Kyle, was initially canceled due to concerns about its depiction of the Middle East. However, after a backlash and a counter-petition, the university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, announced that the film would be shown, emphasizing the university's commitment to freedom of expression. As an alternative, a family-friendly film "Paddington" will also be screened. Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh praised the decision.

Two French tourists allegedly attempted to set a quokka, an Australian animal, on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame caused by the men igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. Detectives questioned the two men, aged 18 and 24, who were living in Cockburn Central, and seized video evidence of the incident. Both were charged with animal cruelty and evicted from the island, with a court appearance scheduled for April 17. Quokkas, which are the size of a domestic cat, are native to small islands off the west Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

A 102-year-old dancer, Alice Barker, who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, was reunited with her past through a video compilation of "soundies"—early music videos—created by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers. Barker, who had never seen any footage of herself dancing due to lost memorabilia, expressed delight upon viewing the video, calling it "fabulous."

The passage highlights a decline in the tradition of British men washing their own cars, with a third admitting they have never done so. Women are even less likely, with three-quarters never washing their own cars. Factors contributing to this decline include the rise of hand car washes, larger vehicle sizes, and changes in weekend routines due to shops being open and more live football on TV. Despite this, car washing increases during holidays, with some using it as an excuse to leave the house. Regional and brand preferences for car washing also vary, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield having higher rates of self-washing compared to Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are more likely to wash their cars themselves, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners are less likely.

The passage highlights Martin Skrtel's praise for Steven Gerrard's impact at Liverpool since his arrival in 2008. Skrtel believes Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and has been crucial in helping him settle at the club. Gerrard, set to leave for LA Galaxy, aims to end his Liverpool career by leading the team to the FA Cup final against Arsenal. Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the team has potential replacements. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are expected to return to the lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving bans.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus, known as the "Golden Bear," achieved a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, adding to his storied career. This was his first ace at Augusta, but the day saw a total of five hole-in-ones, tying a record set in 2002. Nicklaus, who became the youngest to win a Masters in 1963 and won his sixth in 1986, was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. His achievement was briefly overshadowed by Colombian golfer Camilo Villegas, who also scored aces on the fourth and eighth holes but lost in a playoff. Nicklaus is one of five men to complete the career grand slam, a feat Rory McIlroy could achieve by winning his third consecutive major.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN's Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, with three near Aetna. Kansas was not the only affected state; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. On Thursday, more storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he claims he intended to subdue with a taser. The judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which the Harris family criticized as insensitive. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. Bates, 73, was involved in the arrest of Harris during a weapons sting operation in April. Bates maintains the shooting was accidental and has apologized to the Harris family. The family's lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified for the role but received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations. Bates' lawyers released training documents to support his qualifications. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irishman, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. Ahead of the fight, McGregor has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, symbolizing his fierce determination. He claims to have greater motivation than Aldo, who is defending his title for the eighth time. The two have a tense relationship, and McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin, raising it in front of 5,000 supporters.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after he skolled a beer at an event, with critics arguing that his action glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with excessive alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, highlighted the problematic nature of the prime minister showcasing his masculinity through such an act, suggesting it promotes a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was nothing wrong with his behavior, while opposition leader Bill Shorten made a light-hearted comment about Abbott's drinking habits. Dr. Robert emphasized the need for leaders to consider changing attitudes towards heavy drinking, noting the increased concern over binge drinking in recent times.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County, primarily among intravenous drug users. The outbreak is linked to the use of the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. Pence is reviewing reports and may extend the program beyond April 25. The future of the program and similar legislation for other counties is uncertain, as Pence and some lawmakers oppose needle exchanges due to concerns they may promote drug use. The House approved a bill on April 7 to allow needle-exchange programs in counties with high hepatitis C rates, but it faces opposition and funding challenges.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a quiz about the football club, which she scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%). The test included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and an 'in your own words' section. Saskia's boyfriend was impressed with her performance, commenting that she "could have performed better on Q17," needed to "learn all player positions," and should understand that "Tottenham are scum." Saskia posted the test on Twitter, where it received mixed reactions, with some praising her knowledge and others criticizing the boyfriend for taking the quiz too seriously. Despite the criticism, Saskia's boyfriend did not dump her and even graded her an 'A'.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former undercover operative for the DEA, faces deportation despite working for the agency for 27 years. Toro, who was a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel in the 1980s, fled Colombia and began working for the DEA as an informant, providing crucial information that led to the prosecution of high-profile figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Although Toro was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his services, he has not received it and is now living in the U.S. illegally due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship application, leaving him in fear of being sent back to Colombia, where he believes his life would be in immediate danger. Toro remains in limbo, seeking a green card or passport to secure his status and access social security benefits.

A 14-year-old girl in India allegedly set herself on fire after being raped by five men from her village. Her family reportedly told her to remain silent about the attack. She is currently in critical condition at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident occurred when she went outside her home in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, to relieve herself. The accused men have been arrested. This case highlights the ongoing issue of sexual assault in India, which has seen heightened sensitivity and protests following the banning of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of an Indian student in Delhi.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to beat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford, but will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who has been ruled out due to insufficient fitness. Van Gaal expressed his dream of winning the derby, emphasizing the importance of the match in potentially securing a top-three position and avoiding Champions League qualifying fixtures. Despite City's recent defeat, Van Gaal acknowledged the tough challenge they present and downplayed any personal motivation for revenge. Additionally, Luke Shaw has also been ruled out due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal looks forward to the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford and appreciates the support from the fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest at the Emirates Stadium during their Premier League match, leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes to demonstrate against rising ticket prices. The protest followed the Premier League's announcement of a £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans displayed banners both inside and outside the stadium, with one reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," highlighting the high cost of attending matches. The cheapest tickets for the match started at £64, among the highest in the league. Supporters from both clubs gathered outside the 60,000-capacity stadium to protest the increasing costs of modern football. Organizers from Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups called ticket prices "extortionate" and emphasized that football's soul lies with the fans. Further protests are expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia, was saved through a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell. Star's parents, Jade and Matthew, noticed her skin turning yellow shortly after birth, a symptom that persisted, leading to the diagnosis. Neither parent was a suitable match for the transplant, but Shanell, being a twin, proved to be an ideal candidate. She donated part of her liver without hesitation, and Star underwent the successful operation in November. Since then, Star has made a good recovery and must undergo regular blood tests and take anti-rejection medication for life. Shanell also recovered well from the procedure, emphasizing her willingness to help her niece.

In the Audi Football Challenge, Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in various head-to-head challenges. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by shooting balls into a car's boot from close range. They also won the second round by playing tennis over an Audi R8 V10 Plus, which served as the net. In the final challenge, Remy and Willian won by shooting balls through the top of a convertible Audi from long range, despite Willian accidentally smashing a car's wing mirror.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who was previously said to be suicidal, claimed during his sentencing that he was not attempting to kill himself when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into the couple's SUV. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense cited Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis as factors contributing to the crash. Dellinger's wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity, and the family expressed sorrow for the victims' deaths.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she poisoned with salt. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed on Facebook his hope that she would face harsh treatment in prison, stating she "won't make it." Spears appeared emotionless during her sentencing, which was criticized by Hill and the judge, who noted her mental illness. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill to gain attention, while her lawyer claimed she was a loving mother and blamed hospital negligence. Spears' defense plans to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, following a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine's arrival is delayed by a month due to the inclusion of these new strains. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting in April 20. Experts believe the modified vaccine is worth the wait, as it should provide better protection against the circulating strains globally. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasizes the importance of everyone getting the vaccine, not just high-risk groups, to protect those around them who are at higher risk.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, are facing challenges due to an unfavorable critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts. The state of Illinois, which calls itself the "Land of Lincoln," is commemorating the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination amidst a financial crisis. Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, suggesting it be merged into another department. The tomb has been criticized in National Geographic for lacking historical character, described as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." Despite these criticisms, the tomb has undergone recent renovations totaling over $2.5 million, including interior plaster and paint work, and upgrades to the lighting. The tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has faced multiple reconstructions and is currently in excellent physical condition.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, highlighting several items that are making a comeback despite their impracticality or past ridicule. These include JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, extreme fashion trends (like double denim), Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The text notes how these trends were popularized by celebrities in their respective eras and are now being revisited by a new generation of fashion-forward individuals, such as Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, Kylie Jenner, Kristen Bell, Miley Cyrus, Nicki Minaj, Cara Delevingne, and Selena Gomez.

The passage highlights various trending stories from a busy week. Notable events include: the appearance of four rainbows in the New York sky, a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.'s agitation during a Channel 4 interview, the Kardashians-inspired lip plumping trend, a 102-year-old dancer's nostalgic moment, a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's transformation in 'Black Mass', a creative pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad's original photobomb.

The Miami Open has seen a series of celebratory cakes presented to tennis players, with Serena Williams receiving a giant cake after her 700th career victory. This follows Andy Murray's 500th win celebration. Williams advanced to the semi-finals by defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki in a three-set match. Despite her sister Venus Williams' defeat, Serena remains focused on the tournament, which is significant to her as it is held near her hometown. Williams will face Romania's Simona Halep in the semi-finals, after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist, ran a second-floor cafe in Karachi known as T2F, which was a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. She was known for her outspokenness and promotion of free speech, often discussing controversial topics like Balochistan's issues, despite receiving death threats. Mahmud was shot dead by two gunmen, leaving a void in the progressive community in Pakistan. Her death highlighted the dangers of free speech in the country and the ongoing struggle for open dialogue on sensitive issues.

The passage details the plight of Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer and refugee from West Pakistan, who has lived in Indian Kashmir for nearly 70 years without citizenship rights, including the ability to own property or vote in state elections. Ram and thousands like him have been denied these rights due to concerns over upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. The recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in state elections has given them hope for change. Around 100,000 West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) live in the Jammu region, mostly in poverty, with many marrying within their community due to their low economic status. The Bharatiya Janata Party, which has joined a Kashmir governing coalition, is expected to champion the WPRs' cause, potentially granting them state-subject rights and improving their conditions. However, some activists warn that the community is prepared to take matters into their own hands if their hopes for change are not realized.

FCTokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer, following an offer believed to be around £4 million. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to their partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the 22-year-old is keen on joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes he has the potential to succeed at Stamford Bridge due to his intelligence, speed, and confidence. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has acknowledged Muto but refrained from discussing him publicly. The club's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber indicates that commercial interests play a role in their transfer policy.

The passage argues that England should follow Australia's example by selecting their best rugby players regardless of whether they play overseas. It criticizes England's policy of not picking overseas-based players as old-fashioned and detrimental to their World Cup prospects. The author highlights successful overseas players like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage, who have excelled abroad and should be considered for the national team. The argument is that selecting the best players, regardless of their club location, is essential for winning the World Cup, especially as the host nation. The passage concludes by praising Australia for their progressive stance and urging England to adopt a similar approach to maximize their chances of success.

The passage discusses Firechat, an app developed by Open Garden that allows users to chat without needing an internet connection or mobile signal by utilizing wireless mesh networks. Firechat leverages Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) introduced in iOS 7, which enables message and photo sharing through Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct, creating a localized network where each phone acts as a node. The app has been downloaded over five million times and is particularly useful in environments like planes or underground where traditional networks are unavailable.

To enhance the range and strength of these off-the-grid networks, Open Garden has developed Greenstone, a small, egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster. Greenstone extends the range of Firechat messages beyond the typical 200ft (61 meters) limit, with a current operational range of around 20ft (6 meters). The device can store up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life. Greenstone is still in development and its commercial availability depends on partnerships with manufacturers. The combination of Greenstone and Firechat aims to provide resilient communication in various scenarios, such as community networks, hospitals, or large events where traditional

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle is working to change the negative connotations associated with the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive descriptor. During a TED talk, she explained that 'fat' is just another honest self-descriptor, similar to 'short' or 'wife', and should not be synonymous with 'ugly'. Bustle highlighted that societal programming often leads women to deny being 'fat', viewing it as the worst thing one can be. She noted a rise in size discrimination in the workplace and the common desire among young girls to be thinner. However, studies show that increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Bustle uses her burlesque performances to showcase a 'fat' body in a positive light, hoping to change perceptions. She also recommends finding a 'courage reference' moment to boost self-esteem during times of insecurity. Despite some negative comments, her TED talk has received mostly positive feedback, encouraging her belief that body-positivity is gaining ground.

The passage describes Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, frequently being on the bench this season. He and six of his Arsenal colleagues, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has been a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games and hopes to start in their upcoming match against Hull.

A collection of props and puppets from various blockbuster films, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, will be auctioned off on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas." Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" (estimated at $40,000), the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000). The auction spans Baker's 30-year career and includes items from films like "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," and "Batman & Robin," as well as Michael Jackson's "Moonwalker" and the 1983 thriller music video.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, tragically died in the French Alps after falling 164ft while skiing with his family. Described as daring, outgoing, and determined, Carwyn was a competent skier who had started skiing at age three. The family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in Flaine before the accident. Carwyn became separated from his mother and ventured into dense woodland, where he fell to his death. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. The family is devastated, and the community is rallying behind them in support.

The passage details the story of Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay, who developed anorexia due to societal pressures to be a "size zero." Laura became obsessed with her weight, hiding food and lying about eating, often surviving on just one piece of fruit a day. Her condition deteriorated to the point where her body started to shut down, leading to a hospitalization where she was placed on a heart machine. Laura has since spoken out about the pressures on young girls to conform to unrealistic body standards and has been working with eating disorder organizations to recover. She has also gained confidence and made it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to promote positive body image and confidence in young girls.

The passage details the unveiling of Liverpool's new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by New Balance, which replaced Warrior as the club's supplier in a £300 million, four-year deal. Raheem Sterling, along with other players like Daniel Sturridge and Simon Mignolet, presented the new kit to fans at Anfield. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and interest from other clubs, Liverpool fans expressed their desire for him to stay, and the club remains adamant that he will not leave that summer. The kit launch also highlighted the team's focus on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with players expressing their desire to win the cup for the fans and staff.

The University of Manchester researchers have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the night sky. This map, produced using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, is part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map shows clumps of dark matter in red and sparse regions in blue, and it allows astronomers to study how galaxies formed. The DES uses gravitational lensing to detect dark matter's effects on galaxies, as dark matter itself is invisible. The ultimate goal of the survey is to understand dark energy by analyzing the clumpiness of dark matter over time.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, who is a 21-year-old Dutch international. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in his 2014 World Cup squad, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, who recently won the Dutch championship. Despite competition from clubs like Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United appears to be in a strong position to secure Depay's signature.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a third goal. The match saw strong performances from Chelsea's defense, particularly Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, who effectively neutralized City's attack. Manchester City's players, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts and Brandon Barker, showed promise but struggled to find the net consistently. Chelsea's win was solidified by their midfield dominance, with Charlie Colkett leading the charge.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He supports states deciding on gay marriage and does not believe it should be a constitutional right. Despite his personal views, Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, showing respect for their decisions. He also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has received significant financial commitments for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are an adventurous couple from Spain and Latvia who embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their trip in London, cycling through 16 countries in 356 days, covering nearly 7,000 miles. They live on a minimal budget, spending less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their only major expense is food, which costs them 2.74 euros each per day. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent.

A Texas couple married in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth snapshots from their event. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, claims they were not aware of the offensive captions until months after the wedding, when the bride's sister informed them. Evans denies the allegations and has not apologized, prompting the couple to file a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The case is set for mediation, with the couple seeking at least an apology from Evans.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, unsure of when he will return to action for Harlequins. He aims to avoid an extended break by not rushing his recovery. Brown's cautious stance is influenced by the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended absences due to concussions. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, has helped Brown recognize when to withdraw from play, as seen in his decision to pull out before a crucial match against Ireland.

A leading expert suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of couples having sex each month. Research indicates that the frequency of sex among Britons has been decreasing since the advent of the internet. A study by Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, reveals that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the increasing integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, which leaves less "quiet empty time" for intimacy. He also notes that the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world has made lives busier, pushing sex lower on the list of priorities.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in popularity and fortune of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once highly prized and could command prices of up to £1.2 million each. The decline is attributed to several factors, including the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which made it less acceptable to give or receive the dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have significantly impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skins for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued groups of these dogs from cramped cages, some of which were already dead or suffering from injuries. The breed's quality has also deteriorated due to unscrupulous breeding practices driven by profit. The passage also mentions that the rapid pace of urbanization in China has made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

The passage highlights a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed claimed to have experienced sexual harassment on public transport. Half of these women reported being assaulted before the age of 18. The survey found that all female users of mass transit have been victims of gender harassment or sexual assault, often unreported and normalized. Harassment ranges from insults to sex attacks, and it affects women's freedom, leading them to alter their daily routines to avoid confrontation. The survey led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport, emphasizing the need for women to recognize and report harassment and for aggressors to understand the legal consequences of their actions.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily stressors identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top concern was not being able to sleep, leading to the design of "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications. Other issues included forgetting to lock the door, solved by the "Forget Me Lock" device, and running out of phone battery, addressed by "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger. These prototypes were created by groups from Makerversity and are now open for public voting on Twitter. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into a real product.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under investigation for allocating £500,000 of public funds to a charity she co-directs, Victims First Northumbria, which supports crime victims in her area. Sitting alongside her on the charity's board is Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics accuse them of creating a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public money. The Ministry of Justice is probing the matter to determine if any conflict of interest rules were breached. Baird defended her decision, stating all procedures were followed, while Sim announced her retirement from the force in June.

Three people, including ringleader Corey Campbell, have been sentenced to prison for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and accused him of stealing money and drugs. The assault took place over three days in a basement in Philadelphia, where Valecce was restrained and subjected to physical abuse and tattooing with offensive symbols. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact police. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, while his girlfriend, Sandra Ng, received 23 months. Another accomplice, Carl Halin, also received a 20-year sentence. Two others, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, who is 21 years old. United manager Louis van Gaal, who is already familiar with Depay's qualities from their time together with the Dutch national team, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, who recently won the Dutch championship. Despite competition from clubs like Paris-Saint Germain, Manchester United appears to be in a strong position to secure Depay's signature.

Manchester City's players, including Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant, showed resilience but struggled against Chelsea's vibrant attack. The match also featured standout performances from Chelsea's midfielders, Charlie Colkett and Ruben Sammut, who controlled the game.

Qatar Airways, headquartered in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network connecting over 160 international destinations across various continents from its base at Hamad International Airport. The airline utilizes a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.

Qatar Airways, headquartered in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network connecting over 150 international destinations across Africa, Central Asia, Europe, Far East, South Asia, Middle East, North America, South America, and Oceania. The airline's base is at Hamad International Airport, utilizing a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 400 million times globally.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 500 million times globally.

The passage highlights that more than 16,700 people have died and over 102,000 have recovered from a certain event or condition, with the number of deaths and recoveries exceeding previously reported worldwide figures.
The passage reports that over 392,000 cases have been recorded globally, with more than 17,100 deaths and over 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after the latter was substituted in the 83rd minute during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but later admitted his mistake when Townsend scored a crucial equalizer for England against Italy. Despite this, Merson couldn't resist another dig at Townsend after the Tottenham game, leading to a brief exchange on Twitter.

Chelsea has made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto, a Japan international who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the move to Stamford Bridge is completed. The offer is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if the move is finalized. The potential deal is estimated at £4 million, but Muto has not yet decided whether to join the Premier League club.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics, which are used to fatten farm animals, may also contribute to childhood obesity. The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records. It found that children who had taken antibiotics as infants were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain and slightly taller than those not given antibiotics. The study did not prove a direct cause-and-effect relationship but hypothesized that antibiotics might alter gut bacteria, potentially increasing appetite and contributing to obesity. The findings highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, especially given the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an event witnessed by hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was caught on camera, left the guard embarrassed as he lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle. Despite the mishap, he quickly recovered and continued his duties, though he appeared visibly embarrassed. The event is a popular tourist attraction, with guards being fully operational soldiers, not purely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The classic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016. The new version, to be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, will focus on the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake, which aims to be both original and contemporary, drawing more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." The production will consult with scholars for historical authenticity. The remake aims to resonate with a new generation of viewers, considering recent events such as Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar-winning film "12 Years a Slave," as well as ongoing racial issues in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has claimed that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978, on his first day of work. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, said he was accosted in a bedroom by several men, one of whom was a senior staff member. He was pinned to a chair and groped, leading him to leave the job immediately. Lawler, now 64, contacted palace officials again last year after inquiries into alleged child sex abuse cover-ups by a VIP paedophile ring. His complaints were initially ignored, but the police were eventually notified. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was interviewed but denied involvement, claiming he was working elsewhere at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with any police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The Meeks revealed the news after initially lying about not being ready for parenthood, and the video includes a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple found the video's success unexpected and plan to make another video after learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. The dress, originally slate blue-gray but faded to light gray, was worn in key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and during an attack in a shanty town. The collection belonged to James Tumblin, who acquired the dress for $20 in the 1960s and had amassed over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. The boy suffered minor bumps and bruises and was in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs did not approach the child, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

The passage discusses a speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which has been re-angled to point directly at a house's front door. The camera, originally enforcing a 30mph speed limit on the residential road, has been non-functional for over two years due to the decommissioning of all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands in March 2013, as their technology became obsolete. Instead, speed enforcement is now handled by mobile camera units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers. The re-angling of the camera remains a mystery, but Birmingham City Council is aware and will send an engineer to assess the situation, potentially removing the camera. The council is developing a pilot program using digital technology for a limited number of sites but has no plans to include the Wellington Road camera in this initiative.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete as part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his excitement to be part of the team and his readiness to perform, highlighting Jamaica's strong tradition in relays. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) expressed delight at Bolt's availability and anticipated a strong performance from him. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, both teammates at Barcelona, demonstrated their support for the club's basketball side by attending an El Clasico match on Thursday night, where Barcelona won 85-80 in the Euro League. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division due to a points difference. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile in a challenging match, and he and his Barcelona teammates are set to return to La Liga action against Celta Vigo, aiming to continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. There has been a recent surge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean, with Italy registering over 10,000 arrivals in the first three months of 2015. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason for Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, a Chilean forward, was courted by several elite clubs after leaving Barcelona but ultimately chose Arsenal, where he has made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger also praised Sanchez's quick adaptation to the new environment, highlighting his qualities as top-tier. Additionally, Wenger downplayed any speculation about a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, expressing admiration for Brendan Rodgers' management of Liverpool despite the sale of Suarez and injuries to key players.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes and hopes for a capacity crowd to support his attempt. Tickets for the event, which will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, go on sale from April 19. Wiggins' attempt is part of his return to the track, with a goal of achieving a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams, twice French Open champion, described her struggle to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday as an 'eye-opener' for the claycourt season. Despite prevailing 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams acknowledged her unpreparedness for clay courts. The US team was relegated to World Group II after losing the doubles rubber 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. Williams emphasized the need to adapt her game for clay, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez highlighted the team's need to work harder to return to the elite group.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine side from 2001 to 2009. Falcao, who has struggled during his loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, may return to his parent club Monaco or join River Plate. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the team's desire to bring Falcao back, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao has recently shown good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games, tying the national team's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his time at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Pop star Ella Henderson, known for her impressive vocals on The X Factor in 2012, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop, showcasing her versatility. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, noting her regular use of the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste, anticipating a successful 2015 for the partnership.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14, was erected in Kenosham, Wisconsin, causing shock among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal. The police association claims no offense was intended and that the billboard was meant to express gratitude for community support. Torres is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into Siler's death. This incident follows another shooting by Torres, where he wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. Both shootings are under investigation.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. Three militants were also killed by Iranian forces in the fighting in the town of Negur. The militants, who crossed into Iran from Pakistan, are believed to be part of the Jaish al Adal group, which has targeted Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving assailants. Pakistan condemned the attack and is investigating the incident, promising to apprehend and bring to justice any militants who fled back into Pakistan.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan regarding the possibility of extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered any UFOs from outer space. This revelation came in response to a question from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history of interest in UFOs and mixed-discipline matches. Inoki, known for his unique political and entertainment career, asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. This exchange reflects a broader interest in the implications of extraterrestrial visitors, as seen in previous discussions by Japanese politicians.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after he broke a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. Jin had stood on the toilet's rim, concerned about cleanliness, when it collapsed, causing severe injuries. He was found bleeding and was taken to a hospital, where he received dozens of stitches. Initially, Jin confessed to squatting on the toilet but later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident, and a police spokesman reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over a four-year period and filming her and others using a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse began when the girl was nine and continued until she was 13. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation started when the girl discovered a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had specifically purchased the camera to record the girl while she undressed and showered. The preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and Rebbie is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of portraits featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their teenage daughters, aiming to capture a more dynamic and expressive side of the typically serious father-daughter relationship. The images, part of Aoyama's latest book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," show daughters smiling directly at the camera while their fathers perform energetic jumps, often in sharp suits. The series has garnered significant online interest for its unique and curious nature, despite limited information about its origins.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and its potential impact on Kevin Pietersen's chances of returning to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is seen in a reflective mood during a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval before the start of the County Championship season. The event marks a step closer to a possible return to the international set-up for Pietersen, who last played for England during a disastrous Ashes tour in Australia in 2013-14. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test team, with Surrey set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender, was initially fired after a poor run but was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was fired again. The club is now 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who had 25 caps for Brazil, replaced Florin Marin in January and will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, a former Monaco teammate of Radamel Falcao, believes the Colombian striker regrets his loan move to Manchester United despite being unhappy in France. Falcao, who previously played for Atletico Madrid, joined Manchester United on a season-long loan but has struggled to perform at the same level since a serious knee injury. With only four goals scored this season, Manchester United is unlikely to make his transfer permanent, which would cost £46 million. Dirar suggests that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League and felt more comfortable.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. The offender, captured on security footage, made off with the dairy's till and approximately $1500 in cash. The robbery occurred on Saturday when the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop screaming. The police were called to the scene but found no signs of weapons. The robber remains at large, and authorities urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for alleged inappropriate relationships with underage students. In March, she was arrested for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. Subsequently, another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The Irving school district has taken immediate action, placing her on administrative leave to prevent her from interacting with students.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has gone viral, garnering over half a million views. The crocodile, which was seen near a sanctuary 200 meters away, held onto the dog for hours. The dog, belonging to the local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge, likely out of curiosity, but was quickly seized by the crocodile. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the incident while on holiday with his wife, described the scene as a "shock to the system." Social media reactions to the video were mixed, with some expressing horror and others noting the common presence of crocodiles in the area due to its mangrove ecosystem.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, leaving them just two points clear of the drop zone. Bruce initially aimed for 10 wins to survive but now hopes 'nine or eight might be enough.' Hull has six games remaining, including challenging fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, but remains optimistic about avoiding relegation. Southampton, meanwhile, moved to fifth in the table after the win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty designated for James Ward-Prowse.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the entire school's SATs results. Guffick, who worked at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, asked pupils to modify their answers after the exam session had finished. He also altered some answers himself. This led to an investigation by the local education authority, which resulted in the Department for Education annulling all SATs results for the school. Guffick admitted his actions and accepted they amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. Despite his claim that he only asked pupils to make answers more legible, a panel ruled that no changes should be made outside exam conditions. Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years and had 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has struggled for playing time but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard, who joined Manchester United in 2010 from Aalesunds, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his limited on-pitch success, Lindegaard remains content in his personal life with Beqiri, who frequently shares modeling photos on Instagram.

The 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson, failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction, despite expectations of $300,000 to $600,000. Jackson, who bought the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, hoped a new generation would own and enjoy the iconic signage. The letters, installed in 1976, were taken down in 2008. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional conduct after recent incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Despite these issues, neither player will face disciplinary action, and Rodgers aims to move past the incidents. Rodgers is focused on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after a suspension. He emphasizes the importance of learning from setbacks and using them as a part of the journey towards success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, posted a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing with his dog after returning to London following the international break. He had a successful match with Germany, helping them beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who was signed for £42.5 million from Real Madrid in 2013, missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Despite rumors of his activities during his absence, Ozil has been performing well since his return from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He claims to be adjusting well to English football, enjoying the frequent matches and the lack of winter breaks.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has affirmed that there are no plans to replace current manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title with only six games remaining. Bartomeu dismissed speculation about Enrique's potential replacement, highlighting the manager's impressive work, particularly in preparing for crucial matches. The club is content with Enrique's tenure, as Barcelona remains in contention for three major trophies. In a recent match, Enrique's team defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth around £100,000-a-week, which will run until 2020. This follows Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat, and Henderson's current contract had 14 months remaining. The 24-year-old midfielder, signed by Kenny Dalglish in 2011 for £16 million from Sunderland, has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers and has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season.
