The passage describes Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, frequently being on the bench this season. He and six of his Arsenal colleagues, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has been a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games and hopes to start in their upcoming match against Hull.

A collection of props and puppets from various blockbuster films, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, will be auctioned off on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas." Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" (estimated at $40,000), the Two-Face mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000). The auction spans Baker's 30-year career and includes items from films like "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," and "Batman & Robin," as well as Michael Jackson's "Moonwalker" and the 1983 thriller music video.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, tragically died in the French Alps after falling 164ft while skiing with his family. Described as daring, outgoing, and determined, Carwyn was a competent skier who had started skiing at age three. The family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in Flaine before the accident. Carwyn became separated from his mother and ventured into dense woodland, where he fell to his death. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. The family is devastated, and the community is rallying behind them in support.

The passage details the story of Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay, who developed anorexia due to societal pressures to be a "size zero." Laura became obsessed with her weight, hiding food and lying about eating, often surviving on just one piece of fruit a day. Her condition deteriorated to the point where her body started to shut down, leading to a hospitalization where she was placed on a heart machine. Laura has since spoken out about the pressures on young girls to conform to unrealistic body standards and has been working with eating disorder organizations to recover. She has also gained confidence and made it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to promote positive body image and confidence in young girls.

The passage details the unveiling of Liverpool's new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by New Balance, which replaced Warrior as the club's supplier in a £300 million, four-year deal. Raheem Sterling, along with other players like Daniel Sturridge and Simon Mignolet, presented the new kit to fans at Anfield. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and interest from other clubs, Liverpool fans expressed their desire for him to stay, and the club remains adamant that he will not leave that summer. The kit launch also highlighted the team's focus on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with players expressing their desire to win the cup for the fans and staff.

The University of Manchester researchers have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the night sky. This map, produced using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, is part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map shows clumps of dark matter in red and sparse regions in blue, and it allows astronomers to study how galaxies formed. The DES uses gravitational lensing to detect dark matter's effects on galaxies, as dark matter itself is invisible. The ultimate goal of the survey is to understand dark energy by analyzing the clumpiness of dark matter over time.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, who is a 21-year-old Dutch international. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in his 2014 World Cup squad, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, who recently won the Dutch championship. Despite competition from clubs like Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United appears to be in a strong position to secure Depay's signature.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a third goal. The match saw strong performances from Chelsea's defense, particularly Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, who effectively neutralized City's attack. Manchester City's players, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts and Brandon Barker, showed promise but struggled to find the net consistently. Chelsea's win was solidified by their midfield dominance, with Charlie Colkett leading the charge.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He supports states deciding on gay marriage and does not believe it should be a constitutional right. Despite his personal views, Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, showing respect for their decisions. He also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has received significant financial commitments for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are an adventurous couple from Spain and Latvia who embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their trip in London, cycling through 16 countries in 356 days, covering nearly 7,000 miles. They live on a minimal budget, spending less than three euros each per day, relying on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers. Their only major expense is food, which costs them 2.74 euros each per day. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent.

A Texas couple married in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on photo booth snapshots from their event. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, claims they were not aware of the offensive captions until months after the wedding, when the bride's sister informed them. Evans denies the allegations and has not apologized, prompting the couple to file a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The case is set for mediation, with the couple seeking at least an apology from Evans.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, unsure of when he will return to action for Harlequins. He aims to avoid an extended break by not rushing his recovery. Brown's cautious stance is influenced by the experiences of other players like George North and Johnny Sexton, who faced extended absences due to concussions. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, has helped Brown recognize when to withdraw from play, as seen in his decision to pull out before a crucial match against Ireland.

A leading expert suggests that smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of couples having sex each month. Research indicates that the frequency of sex among Britons has been decreasing since the advent of the internet. A study by Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, reveals that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the increasing integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, which leaves less "quiet empty time" for intimacy. He also notes that the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world has made lives busier, pushing sex lower on the list of priorities.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in popularity and fortune of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once highly prized and could command prices of up to £1.2 million each. The decline is attributed to several factors, including the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which made it less acceptable to give or receive the dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have significantly impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skins for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued groups of these dogs from cramped cages, some of which were already dead or suffering from injuries. The breed's quality has also deteriorated due to unscrupulous breeding practices driven by profit. The passage also mentions that the rapid pace of urbanization in China has made people realize that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

The passage highlights a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed claimed to have experienced sexual harassment on public transport. Half of these women reported being assaulted before the age of 18. The survey found that all female users of mass transit have been victims of gender harassment or sexual assault, often unreported and normalized. Harassment ranges from insults to sex attacks, and it affects women's freedom, leading them to alter their daily routines to avoid confrontation. The survey led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport, emphasizing the need for women to recognize and report harassment and for aggressors to understand the legal consequences of their actions.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily stressors identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top concern was not being able to sleep, leading to the design of "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications. Other issues included forgetting to lock the door, solved by the "Forget Me Lock" device, and running out of phone battery, addressed by "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger. These prototypes were created by groups from Makerversity and are now open for public voting on Twitter. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into a real product.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under investigation for allocating £500,000 of public funds to a charity she co-directs, Victims First Northumbria, which supports crime victims in her area. Sitting alongside her on the charity's board is Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics accuse them of creating a conflict of interest and inappropriate use of public money. The Ministry of Justice is probing the matter to determine if any conflict of interest rules were breached. Baird defended her decision, stating all procedures were followed, while Sim announced her retirement from the force in June.

Three people, including ringleader Corey Campbell, have been sentenced to prison for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and accused him of stealing money and drugs. The assault took place over three days in a basement in Philadelphia, where Valecce was restrained and subjected to physical abuse and tattooing with offensive symbols. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact police. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, while his girlfriend, Sandra Ng, received 23 months. Another accomplice, Carl Halin, also received a 20-year sentence. Two others, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.
