The event provides saplings and advises participants to wear appropriate footwear. Brackfield Wood is located seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available for attendees.

The passage highlights Hilary's win of the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate, with the book described as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story." US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her work on detective VI Warshawski. The awards were given at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival, where Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, praised the strong shortlist for the crime novel of the year. Hilary's winning book, "Someone Else's Skin," is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honor crime. Sara Paretsky, known for her 23-year career with VI Warshawski, was also recognized for her impact on crime fiction, particularly for introducing a strong female protagonist and founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a finger injury in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. Despite this, Santner expressed his eagerness to rejoin the team following the ICC Trophy in England, aiming to make an impact with both bat and ball. Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed in 2008 in Kiev by a speeding car with stolen license plates while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), who was 19 years younger, had briefly left him to retrieve a missing glove. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded that Pring was unlawfully killed, noting that his guard was lowered due to inebriation and the car did not brake or stop. Pring's family believes the death was a staged hit-and-run to allow Ziuzina to inherit his assets, which she attempted to claim shortly after his death. The couple met online in 2006 and married after a four-day engagement. Ziuzina, who initially claimed to be a teacher but was actually a lap dancer and stripper, sold Pring's belongings and moved funds from his bank account. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but relaunched it as a murder investigation in 2011, though it remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son Charlie, from Merseyside, requires urgent experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle, America, as the treatment is unavailable in the UK. After a failed transplant, the family was "heartbroken," but they were "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by an anonymous donor who paid for Charlie's treatment. Charlie has been ill since the age of three, and after a third relapse in April, no further treatment options were available in the UK. The family received confirmation via email from Seattle Children's Hospital that the treatment costs had been covered, allowing Charlie to start the therapy as soon as possible.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple's two-step verification system, which requires an extra four-digit code sent to a trusted device, is intended to prevent such breaches. However, this security measure is currently an opt-in choice, and one expert suggests it should be the default. The system also includes a 14-character recovery key for account access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, recognizing the importance of heightened security awareness.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal where Wright would buy 20% of Billericay FC are not yet disclosed. The Sun reported Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity runner-up, will become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who pledged to invest £10,000 weekly. In March, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35.

Mr. Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has given Mr. Ashley until March 21 to respond. The committee invited Mr. Ashley to a public meeting at Westminster, but he has not accepted any of the offered dates. Failure to agree to attend could lead the committee to take further action, potentially involving the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, though the company has previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report, titled "Putin. War," compiled by colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin. The report, based on facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in 2014, accuses President Vladimir Putin of orchestrating the war in Ukraine for personal gain. It presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being decisive in the pro-Russian rebels' victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, with soldiers admitting they were directed into Ukraine for war operations. The report also details the economic cost of the conflict, estimated at 53 billion roubles, and the challenges faced by the opposition in publishing and distributing the report due to fear and censorship. Despite the availability of information, the opposition questions how many people are willing to acknowledge and act on these facts, given the widespread acceptance of Russia's involvement among some Russians.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries, according to a post-mortem. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the tension between the UK government and the devolved administrations, particularly Wales, over the handling of the Article 50 letter. Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration at not being consulted on the letter's drafting, criticizing the lack of respect shown to the devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, emphasizing their commitment to the interests of the whole UK, including Wales. The letter mentions a potential increase in decision-making power for devolved administrations, but specific details on which powers and whether financial support will accompany these changes remain unclear. The passage also hints at potential political and financial implications beyond 2020, with concerns about the continuity of EU funding.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed shock over the "mindless attacks" on PSNI officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page reported that officers were attacked while carrying out their duties, and appealed to parents to monitor their children's activities.

The passage details the ousting of Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of funds. The company's board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claims that many statements made against his client are false and that the company has invaded his privacy to extort him. The court filing includes evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts by Mr. Charney, which he denies. The company asserts that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy, making it unlikely for any board to hire him as CEO or executive. American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game will take place at the Copper Box in London, marking GB's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017 tournament. Greece previously defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, but three Greek players will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game is seen as crucial preparation for GB, with guard Teddy Okereafor expressing excitement about playing at the Copper Box. Following the game, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland, their final warm-up before EuroBasket begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey.

The passage recounts the author's experience during the unveiling of the first iPhone by Steve Jobs in 2007. Initially, the author was unable to get hands-on with the device but managed to briefly use Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller's iPhone for a news segment. The author reflects on the iPhone's revolutionary impact, comparing it to the introduction of the Model T Ford, and discusses how the smartphone has transformed various industries, particularly photography. The passage concludes by acknowledging the iPhone as a pivotal moment in the mobile connected era, leading to the widespread adoption of powerful computing devices and the integration of artificial intelligence in products by companies like Amazon and Google.

A charity confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday, and three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, with another death two weeks prior. The RSPCA is uncertain if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described the cat's symptoms before death, including foaming from the mouth and shivering. Meereen was confirmed to have consumed antifreeze and died three days later. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is urging residents to safely store pesticides and chemicals, especially during the antifreeze-use season, to prevent leaks and clean up spills properly.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government, led by Alexis Tsipras, is preparing to implement further austerity and liberalization measures despite previous opposition. Despite these measures, which include VAT increases, pension cuts, and reductions in farm subsidies, there are no significant protests from the Greek people. This could be due to the calm before the revelation of the terms Tsipras has conceded to secure an €86bn bailout from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and facing monetary austerity due to bank closures. The passage suggests that for the new bailout to succeed, creditors, particularly in Brussels and Berlin, must show debt forgiveness and avoid triumphalism.

Ross Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell, will make a brief return to EastEnders for Dame Barbara's final episodes. Kemp's character, Grant, will reunite with his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, as their mother, Peggy, faces her final moments due to cancer. This return marks a significant event in the soap's history, bringing together two of its most memorable characters, Grant and Phil, to say goodbye to their mother. The storyline is expected to feature emotional scenes and showcase the actors at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, described the moment they were informed of her death by Northumbria Police officers. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice, leading to her stalking. Dr. Hills expressed guilt over reassuring Alice on the phone two days before her death, dismissing her daughter Emma's concerns about Dhillon's potential danger. The parents have since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French firm EDF has approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with one-third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. However, the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has delayed its final decision on backing the project, citing the need for further consideration. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments. EDF's financial capacity has also been questioned, with internal dissent and resignations over the project's risks. The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement, but the delay has sparked uncertainty and criticism from industry leaders and environmentalists, who argue for more investment in renewable energy sources.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales includes a section asking for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery. Family lawyers warn that involving a third party can add conflict and complexity to the process. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name the person, and the form's guidance emphasizes that it is "not normally necessary" to do so. However, some lawyers fear that the presence of the box on the form may encourage people to fill it in, potentially leading to delays and increased costs in the court proceedings. The form has been updated to be more user-friendly, particularly for those who complete the process without legal advice.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental policies and commercial forestry in Wales. It highlights that while the Welsh government encourages the planting of native, broadleaf trees and better access for walkers and bike riders, the timber industry, represented by Confor, warns of a significant loss of commercial forest areas since 2001, which needs to be addressed. The forestry industry is economically important, contributing over £450m annually to the Welsh economy, but faces challenges such as bureaucratic hurdles in creating new woodland areas and conflicts with local residents over timber transportation. The Welsh government aims for a balanced approach in forestry development, emphasizing environmental, economic, and social benefits, as outlined in its Woodlands for Wales strategy. Confor's Martin Bishop argues that the current focus on environmental aspects overshadows commercial forestry and that more needs to be done to meet long-term planting targets.

A boy was severely injured in an incident in Coatbridge, struck near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency services responded at around 16:40, and the boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.

The passage recounts the presentation of Ushakov medals by Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko to veterans of the Arctic Convoys, who supplied the Soviet Union during World War II. Initially, the Foreign Office blocked the award due to rules prohibiting foreign medals for acts more than five years old. Despite this, the British Government introduced the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize the veterans. Last year, an exception was made, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the first Ushakov medals in London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal honors sailors who showed courage defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays in getting offenders to start their unpaid work and noted that many were not penalized for non-attendance. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours of work over 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the issues and is acting on the report's recommendations. Offenders may be required to perform between 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, around 70,000 offenders were ordered to do tasks such as garden maintenance, decorating, or litter-picking. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement, including better organization and enforcement of sentences, and ensuring that offenders are not turned away when they report on time. The chief inspector emphasized the need for urgent action to improve the quality and effectiveness of unpaid work, viewing it as a rehabilitation opportunity rather than just a punishment. The Ministry of Justice aims to ensure offenders attend work on time and face consequences for non-compliance.

The passage discusses a front-page headline in a paper accusing comedian Russell Brand of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. Brand has faced similar accusations before and has defended himself by acknowledging his wealth and fame, but emphasizing the need for personal and systemic change. He argues that his wealth does not detract from the reality of economic disparity and ecological disaster, and suggests that critics may not want inequality on the agenda because it is a real problem. Brand has not responded to inquiries about potential legal action against The Sun, but has been active on Twitter addressing the accusations.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, played a pivotal role in the race to map the human genome, which earned him both acclaim and criticism from the scientific community. His work significantly accelerated the process of genomic research. Following the publication of the human genome, Venter embarked on another ambitious project: creating a synthetic life form. His team at the J Craig Venter Institute successfully developed Synthia, a synthetic organism, which was published in the journal Science. Venter's early life, marked by a shift from surfing to a career in medicine inspired by his experiences in the Vietnam War, led him to excel in research. His innovative approach to gene sequencing, focusing on RNA rather than the entire genome, revolutionized the field. Despite facing criticism and funding challenges, Venter established private research institutes and commercial companies like Celera Genomics, which competed with public projects to decode the human genome. His financial success allowed him to pursue independent scientific endeavors, including the creation of synthetic life forms and oceanic genetic research. Venter's work in synthetic biology has been both groundbreaking and controversial, with potential implications for industrial revolution and environmental sustainability.

The passage highlights a survey conducted by England's School Food Trust, which found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents surveyed reported that their children asked for these new foods to be cooked at home. The survey, involving about 1,000 parents, identified carrots, sweetcorn, and peas as the most popular vegetables among children, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The research was commissioned after a Mumsnet survey suggested that some parents provided packed lunches due to perceived fussiness in their children. The School Food Trust emphasized that school meals can help children try new foods and increase dietary variety. Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted that school meals have evolved with healthier options and more variety, and that children often feel peer pressure to try different foods at school. The survey was conducted online between February 26 and March 5, among parents with children aged 4-17 in school.

Alvaro Morata, 23, is a Spanish footballer currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with a buy-back option for Real reportedly up to 30m euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain in the tournament and 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He has played in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat by Barcelona. Morata, who stands 6ft 3in, began his career at Real Madrid, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

The passage states that Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013. However, he has been without a team since being released in May. During his second spell at Forest, Wilson made 51 appearances. He had previously spent four seasons at Forest before joining Celtic and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County. The passage also mentions that the latest football transfers can be found on a dedicated page.

The British supermarket giant, Tesco, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, and Tesco will loan the new entity £80m. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its inception in 2007. Tesco will incur a £150m cost to dispose of Fresh & Easy, though part of this is a loan that may be repaid. If Yucaipa makes the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Yucaipa, led by billionaire investor Ron Burkle, focuses on supermarket and restaurant businesses. Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years in April.

The passage discusses an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it, eventually considering representing France before targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a special guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

The passage discusses the decline in glacier coverage in the French Alps, particularly in the Mont Blanc Massif and surrounding areas, from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s. This decline represents a 26% loss over 40 years. The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, mirrors similar findings in other Alpine regions. The study, led by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie, utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to verify glacier presence. The retreat is more pronounced in the southern Alps, attributed to lower elevations and different climatic conditions, while the northern Alps, including the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, have seen less significant losses.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their place in the finals. Scotland's forward, Evans, is determined to avoid another play-off loss after missing out on Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches crucial for group leadership. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify directly for the finals in the Netherlands, with the best six of eight group runners-up also qualifying automatically. Evans highlights the importance of fan support and the benefits of having players in top leagues worldwide, which she believes enhances the national team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a vocal Scottish independence campaigner and blogger behind the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following allegations of online harassment made by a woman in south London over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, maintains that the allegations concern some non-threatening tweets. He accused the media of using "innuendo" to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation, and Campbell has been bailed until mid-September. In a statement, Campbell clarified that the alleged events relate solely to some tweets, none of which were threatening.

PETA wants the Skegness mascot, Jolly Fisherman, replaced with a more animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." They argue that Jolly evokes images of animal cruelty, such as fish being impaled and caught in nets. However, the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomes suggestions but doubts there would be much support for axing Jolly, who is beloved by both adults and children. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908, is synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort and promotes the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." The mayor believes Jolly is seen as happy and friendly and does not portray animal cruelty. PETA's suggestion will be considered by the council, but the mayor suggests that if something isn't broken, there's no need to fix it.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland dominated the game, scoring six tries through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), and Hamish Watson. Georgia managed two tries, one by Vasil Lobzhanidze and another from a strong scrum. Scotland's Greig Laidlaw converted multiple tries and penalties, contributing significantly to the score. The match saw Scotland controlling possession and territory, with Georgia struggling to gain ground. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's performance, particularly their ability to maintain possession and counter-attack effectively.

In a rugby league match, Widnes secured a 38-24 victory over Castleford, despite a late comeback attempt by the Tigers. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, and extended their lead to 38-12 in the second half with additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford responded with three quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and a hat-trick by Paddy Flynn, but Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, just one point ahead of the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from the US facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. Odah had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. His release was determined by the Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board in July, which found that his continued detention was no longer necessary to protect against a significant threat to US security. Odah now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release reduces the total number of inmates at the facility to 148. The US opened the Guantanamo Bay facility in January 2002, following the 9/11 attacks, and President Barack Obama has pledged to shut it down.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was celebrated with a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade leading to the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital occurred in 1916, attended by King George V, and has since become significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the crowds, reflecting on the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. The parade included veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families, with crowds lining the streets to watch the ceremony, which featured prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the bloodiest of the war, aiming to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, 30, has rejoined Premiership Well and is set to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been playing mainly as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has been fit all season, has been training hard and playing for the U20s to maintain match fitness. He has made almost 400 senior appearances and has previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson hopes to help the team win more games, build confidence, and push up the table.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were initial concerns about the future of the existing workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including the pension arrangements, will be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, but members currently have an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office, Boparan's private investment, assured the continuation of current pension arrangements. Harley met with Boparan representatives and stated that the new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing existing capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The council held a meeting to address issues with a new ferry, which has faced breakdowns, grounding, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training problems since its launch on 14 May. Cars have been damaged during boarding and disembarking. Council leader Dave Stewart announced the crossing would be free until 2 July to gather feedback and ordered a review by auditors. Local businesses, particularly a shopkeeper, expressed concerns about financial losses due to the ferry's issues. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged initial problems but considered them typical for a prototype, mentioning electrical issues resolved by the company and the authorization of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. Grounding issues, attributed to seamanship, have also been resolved. Compensation for local businesses is under discussion.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting both risks and opportunities. It notes that fishing regions in the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU, hoping to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the House of Lords report warns that the industry, which contributes only a small fraction to the UK's GDP, might be a low priority for the government but must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report also points out that continued market access to the EU may come at the cost of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. Additionally, the UK will need to retain elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and continue to cooperate with neighboring states. The passage concludes with optimism from the fishing industry, which sees Brexit as an opportunity for fairer shares in catching opportunities and more sustainable fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney admitted to downloading images of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He was subject to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special programme for sex offenders. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher, and he was removed from the professional register. The panel concluded that there was a strong likelihood of the offending behavior recurring and deemed him unfit to teach. Geaney was prohibited from re-applying for registration for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site following a fire on 2 March, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm, managed by Asset and Land Group, was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. The company has until 7 August to appeal the EA's decision to revoke its environmental permit, after which it will no longer be able to operate from the site and must remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is making efforts to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mekdad cited attacks on shipments as a reason for delays, emphasizing the ongoing war and security concerns. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where activist groups claim numerous civilian deaths. Mekdad also denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported ongoing fighting and the release of detainees by rebels. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 30 tonnes (4%) reportedly having left the country so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns about the slow progress, but Mekdad reiterated Syria's commitment to fulfilling its obligations under agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

England secured a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. England's Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed with scores of 105 and 76 not out. The win was described as "an absolute hammering" by former England captain Michael Vaughan, who praised England's overall performance. Pakistan's batting was criticized for lacking spirit and discipline, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. The series is expected to remain tight, with Pakistan looking to regain confidence before the next Test.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from those directly affected by residential care, highlighting both positive and negative experiences. The review will assess the quality of life in residential care by examining factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, they express disappointment that no care provider experts are included on the main advisory panel, suggesting a missed opportunity for partnership and full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a former midfielder for Aberdeen, has been appointed as the new manager, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, led the team to their first national trophy and promotion in 2011. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Sheerin was chosen after a comprehensive selection process. Despite Arbroath's chairman, John Christison, wanting to retain Sheerin's services, he understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for several Scottish clubs and also for Östersunds in Sweden before transitioning into coaching. He also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager soon, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis believes Swansea has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, and the team has not been the same since. He thinks the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League, and he reminds new signings of the club's history and importance to the area.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, played a pivotal role in the race to map the human genome, which earned him both acclaim and criticism from the scientific community. His work significantly accelerated the process of genomic research. After the human genome project, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, a project his institute has been working on for over a decade. Born in 1946, Venter's experiences in Vietnam as a naval medic inspired his urgency and determination to excel in medical research. By the 1980s, he was at the NIH, where he pioneered faster gene sequencing methods. His commercial venture, Celera Genomics, aimed to decode the human genome in just three years, challenging the public project's timeline. Despite criticism for his methods, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue his scientific interests independently. In 2006, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute to lead the effort in synthetic biology, culminating in the creation of Synthia, a synthetic organism. Venter has also conducted extensive genetic research on marine microbes, aiming to understand gene evolution and function. His work in synthetic biology has been hailed as potentially leading to a new

The Sutton Trust report highlights that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. It suggests that only a small fraction (less than 200,000 out of 520,000) of apprenticeships in England are at a level equivalent to A-levels, and only 61,000 are for young people, whereas in Germany, 570,000 apprenticeships are for youngsters, with 90% being equivalent to A-levels. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, aiming for 300,000 new starts annually, with the majority at level three or above, to improve job prospects and boost the economy. It criticizes the current system as a "complicated patchwork" that confuses employers and undervalues vocational education. The Department for Education acknowledges the need for reform to "drive up standards" and has already implemented some changes, such as ensuring apprenticeships last a minimum of a year and include more English and maths.

The passage highlights the achievements of British Paralympian Sarah Storey, who recently won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, 37, is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze, earned across both cycling and swimming in six Paralympics. She has won 21 world titles and is targeting further success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Paralympics. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

The passage details the financial struggles and eventual expulsion of Hereford United from the Football Conference. The club faced significant debt, including £148,000 owed to football creditors, and despite multiple deadline extensions, failed to meet the final payment deadline on 12 June. This led to their expulsion, with Chester City being reinstated in their place. Hereford's financial woes were compounded by falling attendance figures and unpaid wages to players and staff. The club was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar, but his tenure did not resolve the financial issues. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust made an offer to buy the club for £1 and clear debts, but it was not accepted. The expulsion marked a sad end for Hereford, who had narrowly avoided relegation on the final day of the previous season.

The passage discusses the career of former Manchester City player, James Milner, who won 61 caps for England after debuting in 2009. Milner was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He announced a decision, stating it was based on common sense and wished the team success under Sam Allardyce. Milner also holds the record for the most caps as an England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting in 2004. His only international goal was scored in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for over 30 years, leading the orchestra across six continents and overseeing the production of more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, which was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He held various academic positions, including at Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. Hogwood was praised for his generosity, academic prowess, and dedication to historically informed music, leaving a significant legacy in the field.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June due to difficulties coping. His parents requested a place at a special school but were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no timeframe for availability. The boy's mother expressed concern over his isolation and the over-subscription of special schools, fearing the same issue for other families. The family was recently informed that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, with hopes of their son starting there soon. The Education Authority is currently reviewing special school needs and aims to ensure places are available near children's homes, with efforts beginning in 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, viewing Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County AFC, who have a lease to use the ground until 2023, are concerned about the potential impact on their Football League status. The WRU's takeover bid will be voted on by shareholders on May 9th. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey assures that both Newport County AFC and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County AFC is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two with two games remaining, and a win this weekend could secure their survival.

The passage recounts the experiences of an individual who survived the civil war in Sierra Leone and later played a significant role in combating the Ebola outbreak in the country. At 15, he was kidnapped by rebels and forced into a life of violence and atrocities, including being initiated into the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) and witnessing horrific acts. After escaping, he struggled to find his relatives and resorted to petty crimes, eventually being caught and meeting a preacher who inspired him to contribute to rebuilding the nation. When the Ebola crisis hit Sierra Leone in 2014, he and others established a clinic to treat suspected cases, focusing on education, support, and treatment. Despite initial resistance and fear, they managed to save many lives. The passage concludes with a reflection on the importance of investing in young people to build a better future.

A collection of about 80,000 art pieces, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, originally at risk of being auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt, was saved through a successful public fundraising campaign. The campaign, led by The Art Fund, reached its target within a month. The collection will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after being gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign's success was attributed to goodwill and determination during negotiations. The collection, deemed important for Staffordshire, was at risk of being sold and scattered globally if the funds had not been raised. The items in the collection are significant for charting Britain's cultural development and defining its national identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal where Wright would buy 20% of the club are not yet disclosed. The Sun reported that Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity runner-up, would become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has a background in non-league football, having played for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed willingness to invest £10,000 weekly. Additionally, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first with a goal by Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized shortly after with a goal by Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had multiple chances to score, including headers against the bar and brilliant saves by the goalkeepers. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. The match saw several fouls, yellow cards, and substitutions due to injuries.

The passage discusses plans to repurpose the disused Fawley power station chimney, which would become the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard, as the centerpiece of a "merchant city" development. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, is set to be transformed into a £1bn development featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 300-acre site, sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, includes the 1971-commissioned, oil-fired Fawley Power Station capable of powering one million homes. Developers plan to retain the 198-meter-high chimney, considering it their signature piece of infrastructure, and envision it as a spectacular attraction with relatively low investment compared to similar projects like the i360 in Brighton or the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth.

The passage details the results of various cycling events at the Hong Kong championships. Jonathan Latham of Great Britain won a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. In the men's team pursuit, GB lost the bronze to Italy. Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and GB's women's team pursuit finished fifth, missing the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, part of the women's team pursuit, remained positive about the team's progress despite not medaling. Katy Marchant, a former Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, will make a brief return to the show for Dame Barbara's final episodes. Kemp, who last appeared in 2006, was approached to reunite the Mitchell family, including his on-screen brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden. The storyline involves Peggy Mitchell's return and her battle with cancer, leading to her eventual death in emotional scenes set to air in the spring. Kemp expressed excitement about returning and filming what are expected to be classic episodes, highlighting the significance of the Mitchell brothers reuniting with their mother for the last time.

In a recent match, Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession, leading to a disappointing performance by second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire to win, stating it would be difficult to compete for the Premier League title if they continue to show such deficiencies. Spurs' recent poor form on the road, including losses and draws against top-six rivals, further complicates their title challenge. Pochettino acknowledged that if Chelsea extends their lead, it would be a significant problem for Spurs. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy noted that Spurs' defensive record, which was strong in previous seasons, faltered in this match, suggesting a need for a change in tactics and mindset when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the recent elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll, is set to be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's decline was further highlighted by its losses in key northern states and its failure to secure a national spread of votes, performing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC, however, did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose challenges for Buhari in terms of oil revenue and militant disruptions. Despite some violence during the elections, the overall process was more peaceful than in previous years, suggesting a maturing democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader, as voters sought a change after 16 years of PDP rule.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22. This year, visitors can use a special app to access augmented reality features, including online information triggered by signs and posters on-site. The app will provide access to videos, band interviews, and other content on phones and tablets. Notable acts this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this new feature aims to enhance the festival experience for attendees and allow people worldwide to interact with the event and experience its atmosphere. The app will be updated before and during the festival, enabling users to access information, interviews, purchase tickets, and get a sense of the unique festival atmosphere from anywhere.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, face potential funding loss unless concerns are addressed. A head teacher at one of the schools, part of the Trojan Horse controversy, described feeling isolated and undermined by parents during an Ofsted inspection. Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted by a hardline Muslim takeover, with five, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council plans to work with affected schools and the Department for Education to install temporary governing boards. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the management of Park View and Nansen, leading to the termination of their funding agreements. The Park View School spokesman indicated they would challenge the Ofsted report legally. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock were given lists of demands to address their inadequacies. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw highlighted a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools, with reports of an organized campaign to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. The report on Park View School criticized its inadequate measures to keep students safe

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges that eye specialist Honey Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test, which led to a build-up of fluid in his brain and ultimately his death. The prosecution claims her conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal." Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with a man he arranged through an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit video to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014 and was convicted of causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to the severity of his crimes. The victim felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg, and the judge emphasized the need for a sentence that reflects society's abhorrence of such conduct. Weatherhogg, assessed as posing a "moderate risk" of sexual re-offending, was a first offender.

In a T20 cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson making 56 and Gary Wilson and captain William Porterfield contributing 41* and 39 respectively. However, Afghanistan achieved their target of 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early on, but Thompson and Porterfield steadied the innings. Afghanistan's opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai helped them cruise to victory. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only bowler with more than one wicket. Ireland's captain Porterfield acknowledged they fell short of a potentially big score and didn't execute their bowling as well as they wanted. The absence of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was another setback for Ireland. The teams will meet again in the second T20 on Friday, with Rankin expected to return for the five ODIs starting on 15 March.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the transfer of Neymar from Santos to Barcelona. Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of the transfer, including wages, agents' fees, and taxes, amounted to £106.8m. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned following accusations of misappropriation of funds, though he denies any wrongdoing. The club faced allegations that the actual cost of Neymar's transfer was higher than initially disclosed. A Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona made a supplementary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address potential tax discrepancies, but it remains unclear if this will resolve the case. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK Metropolitan Police officers collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects. The UK detectives have completed their review and will compile a report to update the families of the victims. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21-year-old migrant workers from Myanmar, confessed to the murders but Thai police deny reports of confession withdrawal. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, facing the death penalty if convicted. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of suspects. The UK police visit followed an agreement between Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha and UK Prime Minister David Cameron. Post-mortem results indicated Miller died from drowning and head trauma, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police confirmed DNA evidence linked the suspects to the crime.

The passage discusses the Scottish women's football team's current position in their qualifying group for a major tournament, with a crucial match against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. The team has won all five qualifiers so far and a victory against Iceland would almost secure their place in the finals. The team has previously faced disappointment in play-offs for Euro 2013 and the World Cup, making this opportunity particularly significant. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten, making the upcoming matches decisive for the group's top spot. The Scottish team, with players from various top leagues around the world, believes their international experience benefits the national team, enhancing their chances of reaching the finals. The support of fans is also highlighted as crucial for their performance.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple's two-step verification system, which requires an extra four-digit code sent to a trusted device, was not previously enforced during iCloud backups, allowing attackers to download data. Apple is now implementing changes to prevent this, including notifications to account owners when backups start and making two-step verification more secure. However, the system remains an opt-in choice, with some experts advocating for it to be the default. Concerns remain about the usability and security of recovery keys, which are necessary if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage details the campaign expenditures of various UK political parties during the 2014 European election. UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent slightly more at £2,980,815. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, and the Liberal Democrats, who lost all but one of their MEPs, spent £1,580,575. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249. The total spending for the six highest-spending parties, including the SNP, amounted to £9,347,087. The passage also notes the cost per vote for each party, with UKIP spending 68p per vote, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, and the Liberal Democrats £1.45.

The passage discusses the transfer of two players to National League rivals: centre-back Anderson, 27, who has left Barrow by mutual consent, and striker Keating, 21, who was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Anderson, with experience in Italy and previous clubs like Aldershot and Exeter, may face his old team on 18 February. Keating, previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, requires international clearance for his move. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson highlights Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's potential despite his youth. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur even in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite previous episodes of post-race ataxia, where the horse showed symptoms of overheating and instability, Many Clouds had never collapsed before and had no symptoms of ataxia during the race. The incident has prompted a call for further research to understand and potentially prevent such occurrences in the future.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament. Both Salmond and McNeil, along with former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie, are among those stepping down ahead of the May 5 election. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized in his valedictory address that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and highlighted the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but argued it did not fulfill unionist pledges made during the referendum campaign. McNeil, who has served since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Goldie joked about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service to the parliament and Scotland.

The passage discusses the casting and production details of the live-action adaptation of the film "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Belle's father, Maurice, and Emma Thompson will voice Mrs. Potts, a role originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury. Josh Gad, known for his role as Olaf in "Frozen," will play Gaston's sidekick, LeFou. The film is directed by Bill Condon and is set to be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, with filming beginning at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to reveal its decisions regarding potential charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured. The suspects include individuals investigated for the causes of the disaster and those probed for the conduct of police forces in the aftermath. Relatives of the victims will be informed of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster and is chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope that this marks the end of the journey for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with one former inmate describing the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the hard work of staff in preventing contraband but emphasizes the need for further action, with the Justice Secretary requesting a review of tools to tackle this issue. A local resident reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, expressing concern but not fear. The former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, though the Ministry of Justice denies evidence of this at Chelmsford Prison. New laws have been introduced, allowing for up to two years in prison for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in December after being struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. The driver, Brian Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, who had been on duty for 20 years, was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road when Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light and hit her. Wright expressed deep remorse for the incident, which has left Mrs. Blackburn in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses the dilemma faced by Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir, who is also a veterinary medicine student. Muir, who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her university exams scheduled for May. She expresses disappointment but prioritizes her degree, emphasizing its importance. Muir also mentions her potential participation in the World Indoor Championships in March and her aspirations for future Olympics. She achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds, showcasing her potential for future competitions.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man, was last seen in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations, began in 2023 and is expected to last several weeks. Earlier in the year, detectives reviewed Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage showing him talking to a man in black outside his workplace. The man has not been identified and remains a key focus of the investigation.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, secured a victory over Swiss player Stan Wawrinka in a four-set match, marking his return to Grand Slam tennis after three wrist surgeries. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, expressed joy at his win and the support from the crowd. Meanwhile, Australia's Nick Kyrgios overcame a rain-affected match to advance to the third round, setting up a potential meeting with Andy Murray in the last 16. Other notable wins included those by Spanish 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez and top-ranked players Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf, which were resolved after an apology. Morocco's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was initially banned but reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both countries experienced issues related to hosting and participation, but Morocco's FA chief expressed optimism for the future. Tunisia's dispute with Caf centered on a contentious penalty awarded during a 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a demand for an apology or disqualification. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament was secured after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Tunisia and Morocco were drawn into different groups for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia potentially setting a record for consecutive appearances if they qualify.

The passage discusses the decline of the McLaren Formula 1 team from its past glory, marked by 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team currently struggles with a fourth-row grid position and Honda power-unit issues. The slump began in 2013 with chassis design problems and has continued, contrasting with their successful partnership with Honda in the 1980s. McLaren's history shows a cycle of triumph and decline, with notable periods of dominance followed by setbacks. Team boss Ron Dennis remains optimistic about the team's future, believing they will break Mercedes' dominance and achieve success again.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven for a sudden death incident. Police found the bar still open with alcohol served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defense acknowledged lax adherence to licensing laws, and the judge noted O'Neill's poor record, fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to help the Golden State Warriors defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 set two years ago. Teaming with Klay Thompson, Curry led the Warriors back from a 13-point deficit. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, dealing a significant blow to Miami's playoff hopes.

The passage describes a surprise visit by YouTube star Bas van Velzen to Liverpool's training ground, Melwood, where he met players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. Initially, the players believed Van Velzen was a competition winner there for a dead-ball masterclass. However, it soon became apparent that Van Velzen was a skilled free-kick specialist, surprising the Liverpool players with his abilities. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube videos showcasing free-kick skills, enjoyed the experience of playing with his football idols and found satisfaction in surprising the players with his talent. The visit concluded with Van Velzen revealing a t-shirt featuring Balotelli's infamous slogan.

The passage discusses how women carrying the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed, a procedure known as oophorectomy. A study found that oophorectomy reduces the risk of breast cancer death by 62% in women with a BRCA1 mutation, with a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The protective effect of oophorectomy was found to be immediate and lasting for 15 years. The study also highlighted that oophorectomy was particularly effective for survival benefit in women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. However, the procedure did not show the same benefits for women with a BRCA2 mutation. The researchers called for further studies, especially on BRCA2 carriers, and suggested that oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers at the time of breast cancer diagnosis.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train (No. 80, the Carolinian) on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on the tracks. The train, which was heading from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes but continued its route without any injuries to the 166 passengers, though one person fell ill during the delay and received treatment. Authorities believe the couple may have been living in a homeless camp, as suggested by a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. The accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former undercover DEA informant who worked for 27 years in exchange for a promise of US citizenship, is facing deportation despite his extensive service. Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s and provided crucial information that led to the prosecution of high-profile figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro was not granted citizenship and now lives in the US illegally due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him, leaving him in fear of being sent back to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed. Toro remains in limbo, seeking a green card or passport to secure his status and access social security benefits.

The US body responsible for regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for allegedly using the '.sucks' domain name to charge high fees from celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Notable names like Kevin Spacey, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have been targeted. ICANN initially approved the '.sucks' domain but is now reconsidering after complaints from industry groups and major companies. Vox Populi charges $2,499 per year for these domain names, which are often resold for around $2,000. ICANN has sent a letter to US and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, with potential consequences including contract breach and changes to the registry's behavior.

A woman was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. DNA evidence led to her identification as the mother. She explained that she had concealed the pregnancy and the baby's stillbirth from her family and friends, placing the body in the pond. The case was reviewed, and the baby's body was exhumed and reburied with a new headstone named "Peter" after the church. Police ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car driven by Young. The incident occurred in 2010 when Hicks, then 23, was returning home with his girlfriend from a night out in Bath, Somerset. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank, leading Hicks to jump out of the car at over 20mph. Hicks sustained devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of what the family had requested, potentially in the hundreds of thousands of pounds.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, less than 15 miles west of Wichita, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. CNN's Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, with three near Aetna. Kansas was not the only affected state; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. On Thursday, more storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight bout in New Jersey. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive win since his loss to Vitor Belfort, believes he can dominate Machida by being aggressive and cutting off his movement. He sees Machida's style as evasive and plans to exploit perceived weaknesses. Rockhold respects Machida's skills but is determined to showcase his own style and secure a title shot. Machida, also coming off a victory, is confident in his technique and strategy, believing he can upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters acknowledge mutual respect but are focused on securing a win.

A light general aviation aircraft, piloted by Chris Georgaklis, attempted a landing at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear. The plane skidded along the runway on its belly, causing damage to the propellers. Despite the damage, the pilot managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The incident, likely due to human error, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. City is considering offers for Toure as they aim to overhaul their ageing squad. Despite Toure's underperformance, Pellegrini dismissed the idea of giving him a rest and emphasized his importance to the team. Meanwhile, goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the team's responsibility for disappointing performances and stated that Pellegrini retains the support of the dressing room. Additionally, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned left-back Aaron Cresswell against moving to Manchester City, citing the lack of playing time for other English players who have joined the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his extradition to Italy was halted. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was sentenced to seven years in prison by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. Despite losing his battle against extradition in February 2014, it was revealed that his case expired in October 2014, leading to the withdrawal of his European Arrest Warrant. Although his conviction remains, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished if more than double the penalty time has passed. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, expressed confidence that the Italian government would withdraw the arrest warrant, allowing him to live peacefully in England with his family. The case will still need to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, but Rancadore does not need to be present.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The Paul Nicholls-trained horse is grouped with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. Mr. Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final day's book of rides will be finalized on Friday morning. The race also includes Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance, but Ritter was advised not to see the crime scene photos. After 40 years, Ritter decided to view the photos, describing the horrific state of her daughter's body. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He aims to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. McIlroy views winning the Masters as a career-long goal and a special achievement. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he is determined to win at Augusta. McIlroy considers his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. He hopes to use the golf course as his sanctuary from external pressures and distractions.

The passage highlights various trending stories from a busy week. Notable events include: the appearance of four rainbows in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; the Chinese government's crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes; Robert Downey Jr.'s irritation during a Channel 4 interview; the rise of the #KylieJennerChallenge for lip plumping; 102-year-old Alice Barker's nostalgic experience with filmmakers; a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp's transformation in the 'Black Mass' trailer; a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"; and a military dad's original photobomb. These stories all trended on social media during the week.

The passage reveals that 272 children were hospitalized in England over the past year due to disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), a condition resulting from exposure to alcohol in the womb. Experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be much higher. Research by the World Health Organization suggests that at least 1 in 100 babies in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 cases annually.
